3833: अन्तर्गिरम् Avyayībh. In the mountain or mountains. Also अन्त-र्गिरि. E. अन्तर् and गिरि, samās. aff. टच्; or अन्तर् and गिरि.
3834: अन्तर्गुदवलय Tatpur. m. (-यः) (In Medicine.) The sphincter ani. E. अन्तर्-गुद and वलय.
3835: अन्तर्गूढविष Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-षः-षा-षम्) With poison hidden in the interior, in the heart; e. g. अन्तर्गूढविषो वहिर्मधुम-यश्चातीव मायापटुः ।. E. अन्तर्-गूढ and विष.
3836: अन्तर्गृह I. Tatpur. n. (-हम्) The inner apartments of a house: the cooking apartment, the hall, the gynæceum &c. II. Avyayībh. (-हम्) In the interior of a house. Comp. अन्तर्गेहम्. E. अन्तर् and गृह.
3837: अन्तर्गेहम् Avyayībh. In the interior of a house. Comp. अन्तर्गृह. E. अन्तर् and गेह.
3838: अन्तर्घण Tatpur. m. (-णः) 	1 An open place between the gate and the house. 	2 The name of a village in the country of the Bāhīkas (or Bāhlīkas). Also अन्तर्घन. E. हन् with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. अप्.
3839: अन्तर्घन Tatpur. m. (-नः) The same as the preceding.
3840: अन्तर्घात Tatpur. (-तः) Striking in the middle. E. हन्, with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. घञ्.
3841: अन्तर्ज Tatpur. m. f. n. (-जः-जा-जम्) Produced in the in-terior (of the body). E. अन्तर् and ज.
3842: अन्तर्जठरम् Avyayībh. In the belly. [As an explanation of कोष्ठ in the Amarak. thus commented upon: अन्तर्जठरे उद-रान्तर्देशे अन्तर्जठरम् । अन्तःशब्दस्याधिकरणप्रधानत्वाद्विभ-क्त्यर्थेऽव्ययीभावः.] E. अन्तर् and जठर.
3843: अन्तर्जम्भ Tatpur. m. (-म्भः) The jaws. (ved.) E. अन्तर् and जम्भ.
3844: अन्तर्जल I. Tatpur. n. (-लम्) 	1 The water in the interior; e. g. of a cloud, स्तम्भितान्तर्जलौघः. 	2 The interior of the water; comp. मध्येजल; but अन्तर्जले may be taken also as two separate words, e. g. अन्तर्जले उभे सन्ध्ये प्राणायामेन शुद्ध्यति (where the neglect of Sandhi °ले उ° is either a misprint in the Mitākṣara or a liberty of Parāsara who in a pre-vious verse writes मयूरमेषौ हत्वा च एकभक्तेन शुद्ध्यति (for it seems impossible to interpret अन्तर्जले in that passage otherwise than as a locat. of a Tatpur. or as अन्तर् and जले). II. Avyayībh. (-लम्) In the water. E. अन्तर् and जल.
3845: अन्तर्जलचर Tatpur. m. f. n. (-रः-री-रम्) Moving in the water. E. अन्तर्जल and चर.
3846: अन्तर्जानु Bahuvr.(?) m. f. n. (-नुः-नुः-नु) Having placed the hands between the knees; (this word occurs in Yājna-valkya where it is explained by the Mitākṣara जानुनोर्मध्ये हस्तौ कृत्वा; a various reading is the Avyayībh. अन्तर्जानु). E. अन्तर् and जानु.
3847: अन्तर्ज्योतिस् Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-तिः-तिः-तिः) Looking into one's own heart (not on outward pleasure; comm. ‘अन्तरेव ज्योतिर्दृष्टिर्यस्य न नृत्यादिषु’). [In the passage of the Śata-paṭhabr. and Bṛhadār. योऽयं विज्ञानमयः प्राणेषु हृद्यन्त-र्ज्योतिः पुरुषः, the words अन्तर् and ज्योतिस् do not form a compound, but अन्तर् refers to the preceding हृदि.] Com-pare अन्तःसुख and अन्तराराम. E. अन्तर् and ज्योतिस्.
3848: अन्तर्ज्वलन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) Internal heat. E. अन्तर् and ज्वलन.
3849: अन्तर्दग्ध Tatpur. m. f. n. (-ग्धः-ग्धा-ग्धम्) Burnt inwardly; e. g. विषेणान्तर्दग्धः. E. अन्तर् and दग्ध.
3850: अन्तर्दधन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) A ferment, a drug or seed used to produce fermentation at the distillation of spirituous liquors. [It occurs in the Śabdachandrikā: संधाने सूत्परं प्रोक्तं किण्वेऽन्तर्दधनं विपम्.] E. अन्तर् and दधन (from दध्, the older form of दह्, kṛt aff. ल्युट्).
3851: अन्तर्दधान Tatpur. m. f. n. (-नः-ना-नम्) 	1 Disappearing. 	2 Concealing one's self (from, with a noun in the abl.) e. g. अन्तर्दधानां रक्षोभ्यः. E. धा with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. शानच्.
3852: अन्तर्दशा Tatpur. f. (-शा) (In Astrology.) The configuration of the minor planets considered as influencing the fortune of man; it is included in and modifies the महादशा or con-figuration and sway of the predominant planet; see also दशा. E. अन्तर् and दशा.
3853: अन्तर्दशाधिपति Tatpur. f. (-तिः) The Lord or the principal planet of an अन्तर्दशा q. v. E. अन्तर्दशा and अधिपति.
3854: अन्तर्दशाह Tatpur. m. (-हः) A period of time within ten days. [I may observe that the only passage, to my knowledge, where this word is not used in the locative viz. in the present editions of Manu 8. 222, where it occurs in the ablat. अन्तर्दशाहात् has a various reading in the Vivādachintām. p. 56. 1. 12 अन्तर्दशाहे which appears to be preferable (the Mitākṣ. in both editions of the Vyavah. section p. 70 a. 1. 10 and p. 264. 1. 7 as well as the E. I. H. Mss. of it agree with the edd. of Manu); but if the reading °हे be correct, and the word did not occur in another case but the loc., it would become doubtful whether अन्तर्दशाहे does not represent two distinct words instead of a com-pound.] E. अन्तर् and दशाह.
3855: अन्तर्दाव Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-वः-वा-वम्) Burning within, having fire within. (ved.) E. अन्तर् and दाव.
3856: अन्तर्दाह Tatpur. m. (-हः) Inward heat, heat within the body; e. g. कक्षाभागेषु ये स्फोटा जायन्ते मांसदारुणाः । अन्तर्दाहज्वरकरा दीप्तपावकसंनिभाः; also figur. of grief, anger &c. E. अन्तर् and दाह.
3857: अन्तर्दुःख Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-खः-खा-खम्) Aggrieved, af-flicted. E. अन्तर् and दुःख.
3858: अन्तर्दुष्ट Tatpur. m. f. n. (-ष्टः-ष्टा-ष्टम्) Inwardly bad or wicked. E. अन्तर् and दुष्ट.
3859: अन्तर्दृष्टि Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-ष्टिः-ष्टिः-ष्टि) Looking into one's own heart or mind; comp. अन्तर्ज्योतिस्. E. अन्तर् and दृष्टि.
3860: अन्तर्देश Tatpur. m. (-शः) An intermediate region of the compass; comp. also अन्तरदिशा. E. अन्तर् and देश.
3861: अन्तर्द्वार Tatpur. n. (-रम्) A private door within the house; the interpretations of this word vary; according to the different comm. it would imply 	a. A private or secret door of a house in general. 	b. A secret door of a mansion &c. (सुधादौ गुप्तद्वारम्). 	c. A court-door (प्रकोष्ठद्वारम्). 	d. A treasury door (कोष्ठकद्वारम्). 	e. A side or back-door, a sally-port (पक्षद्वारम्). 	f. A window, a wicket, an eyelet-hole (जालद्वारम्). It corresponds with the Hind. खिडकी or खिडकिका. E. अन्तर् and द्वार.
3862: अन्तर्द्वीपिन् m. pl. (-पिनः) The name of a people. E. अन्तर्-द्वीप, taddh. aff. इनि, or perhaps a Tatpur. अन्तर् and द्वीपिन्.
3863: अन्तर्धा Tatpur. (-र्धा) 	1 Concealment, covering. 	2 Disap-pearance. E. धा with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. अङ्.
3864: अन्तर्धान Tatpur. 1. n. (-नम्) 	1 Concealment, covering. 	2 Disappearance, invisibility; also considered as one of the forms assumed by Brahman (m.) in the process of creation, according to the Bhāgavata Purāṇa. In the Yoga philo-sophy it means the capacity of making himself inaccessible to the senses, acquired by a Yogin through applying the highest degree of meditation to the notions of Shape, Sound &c.: कायरूपसंयमात्तद्ग्राह्यशक्तिस्तम्भे चक्षुःप्रकाशासंप्र-योगे (v. 1. °शासंयोगे) ऽन्तर्धानम् ‘Disappearance arises from संयम (the highest degree of meditation which com-prises धारणा, ध्यान and समाधि qq. vv.) being applied to Shape which inheres to Body, since thus the power (or possibility) of being seized by that--viz. the eye--is stopped and the clearness of vision has ceased to be’; this definition, add the commentators, implies also that the Yogin becomes inaccessible to the sense of ‘hearing &c.’ when the same meditation extends to the notion of ‘Sound &c.’ 2. m. (-नः) A proper name; a son of Pṛthu and the father of Havirdhāna; also called अन्तर्धि. E. धा with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. ल्युट्.
3865: अन्तर्धापित Tatpur. m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) 	1 Made invisible. 	2 Made irrecognizable; e. g. ततो नलो विरूपो बभूव । नाग-स्त्वाह । जनास्त्वां न जानन्त्विति रूपमन्तर्धापितम्. E. धा, in the caus., with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. क्त.
3866: अन्तर्धायक Tatpur. m. f. n. (-यकः-यिका-यकम्) Covering, concealing. E. धा with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. ण्वुल् and āgama युक्.
3867: अन्तर्धि Tatpur. 1. f. (-धिः) and 2. m. (-धिः) The same as अन्तर्धान q. v. E. धा with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. कि.
3868: अन्तर्ध्यान Tatpur. n. (-नम्) Profound inward meditation. E. अन्तर् and ध्यान.
3869: अन्तर्नगर Tatpur. n. (-रम्) A palace. Comp. अन्तःपुर. E. अन्तर् and नगर.
3870: अन्तर्निविष्ट Tatpur. m. f. n. (-ष्टः-ष्टा-ष्टम्) Gone within, placed within, being within; e. g. अन्तर्निविष्टोज्ज्वलरत्न-भासः. E. अन्तर् and निविष्ट.
3871: अन्तर्निष्ठ Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-ष्ठः-ष्ठा-ष्ठम्) Absorbed in medi-tation, contemplative. E. अन्तर् and निष्ठा.
3872: अन्तर्भव Tatpur. m. f. n. (-वः-वा-वम्) Inward, internal, generated internally. E. अन्तर् and भव.
3873: अन्तर्भवन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) The interior of a mansion, an inner mansion. E. अन्तर् and भवन.
3874: अन्तर्भाव Tatpur. m. (-वः) 1. Inclusion, the being included or comprehended by; e. g. विपर्ययाशक्तिषु यथायोगं धर्मा-दीनां ज्ञानवर्जमन्तर्भावः; or सर्वाकारमहंकाररहितत्वं व्रजन्ति चेत् । अत्रान्तर्भावमर्हन्ति दयावीरादयस्तदा (viz. by the rasas). E. भू with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. घञ्. 2. Interior disposition, inward feeling(?). E. अन्तर् and भाव.
3875: अन्तर्भावना Tatpur. f. (-ना) ‘ 	1 Inward thought or anxiety. 	2 (In Arithmetic.) A mode of composition or rectification of numbers by the differences of the products.’ (Carey.) E. अन्तर् and भावना.
3876: अन्तर्भावित Tatpur. m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) Implied; e. g. अन्तर्भावितोऽत्र ण्यर्थः ‘the causative sense is there implied (sc. by the form अधास्यत्)’. E. भू in the caus. with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. क्त.
3877: अन्तर्भिन्न Tatpur. m. f. n. (-न्नः-न्ना-न्नम्) Inwardly rent. E. अन्तर् and भिन्न.
3878: अन्तर्भूत Tatpur. m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) 	1 Included, compre-hended; e. g. महाभूतेष्वन्तर्भूतास्त्रयो लोकाः. 	2 Internal, in-terior. E. भू with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. क्त.
3879: अन्तर्भूतत्व n. (-त्वम्) The same as अन्तर्भाव 1.; e. g. प्रथमा-लापे द्वितीयालापस्यान्तर्भूतत्वात् ‘since the second condition of the (algebraic) problem is comprehended in the first’. E. अन्तर्भूत, tadd. aff. त्व.
3880: अन्तर्भूमि Tatpur. f. (-मिः) The interior of the earth. E. अन्तर् and भूमि.
3881: अन्तर्भूमिगत Tatpur. m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) Gone into, being in, the interior of the earth. E. अन्तर्भूमि and गत.
3882: अन्तर्भूमिनिवासिन् Tatpur. m. f. n. (-सी-सिनी-सि). Living or being in the interior of the earth; e. g. °सीनि सत्त्वानि. See the following. E. अन्तर्-भूमि and निवासिन्.
3883: अन्तर्भौम m. f. n. (-मः-मा-मम्) The same as the preceding. E. An irregular derivation from अन्तर् and भूमि, taddh. aff. अण्.
3884: अन्तर्मनस् Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-नाः-नाः-नः) Sad, perplexed, melancholy. (Comm. lit. ‘whose mind is engaged with in-terior, not with exterior objects’.) E. अन्तर् and मनस्.
3885: अन्तर्मानवती f. (-ती) A proud or coy woman; a female character in erotic poetry, described e. g. Amaruśataka v. 82. E. अन्तर्-मान, taddh. aff. मतुप्.
3886: अन्तर्मुख 1. m. f. n. (-खः-खा-खम्) Being in the mouth. 2. n. (-खम्) A surgical instrument of the shape of a crescent and seven fingers in length; it is used for removing fluids, as pus, blood &c. E. अन्तर् and मुख.
3887: अन्तर्मृत Tatpur. m. (-तः) Died in the uterus; अन्तर्मृतः शिशुः ‘a dead fœtus’. E. अन्तर् and मृत.
3888: अन्तर्मोद I. Tatpur. m. (-दः) and II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-दः -दा-दम्) The same as अन्तःप्रमोद. E. अन्तर् and मोद.
3889: अन्तर्य m. f. n. (-र्यः-र्या-र्यम्) Being within, in the middle. E. अन्तर, taddh. aff. यत्.
3890: अन्तर्याम Tatpur. m. (-मः) The name of one of the ग्रह or liba-tions made with the juice of the Soma plant. E. अन्तर् and याम.
3891: अन्तर्यामग्रह Karmadh. m. (-हः) The same as अन्तर्याम, or the act of making the libation. E. अन्तर्याम and ग्रह.
3892: अन्तर्यामपात्र Tatpur. n. (-त्रम्) The vessel out of which the Antaryāma libation is made. E. अन्तर्याम and पात्र.
3893: अन्तर्यामिन् Tatpur. m. (-मी) 	1 (In the Upan. and the oldest Vedānta phil.) The supreme Soul as the inward regulator of all the phenomena of the material and intellectual world, in this and in a future life: ‘य इमं च लोकं परं च लोकं सर्वाणि च भूतान्यन्तरो यमयति’; ‘अधिदैवतमधिलोकमधि-वेदमधियज्ञमधिभूतमध्यात्मं च कश्चिदन्तरवस्थितो यमयिता-न्तर्यामी’; not merely ‘the individual Soul of a divinity, of a living being &c.’, but the same as the परमात्मन्; ‘अन्तर्याम्य-धिदैवादिषु तद्धर्मव्यपदेशात्’…‘तस्मात्परमात्मैवान्तर्यामी’.--	2 (In the later Vedānta.) Brahman (m.) as creator of the world when under the influence of the first Gunā or of the cosmical quality of सत्त्व ‘goodness’; as such however, he is not the purest form of Brahman, but inferior to Īśa who is freed of all cosmical qualities. 	3 (In the Vedānta applied to the doctrine of the sects.) 	a. Viṣṇu or Purushottama when be-coming human or individual Soul; e. g. अन्तः प्रविश्य भूतानि यो बिभर्त्यात्मकेतुभिः । अन्तर्यामीश्वरः साक्षात्पातु नो यद्वशे स्फुटम् ॥; 	b. Śiva. E. अन्तर् and यामिन्.
3894: अन्तर्लम्ब Bahuvr. n. (-म्बम्) (In Geometry.) An acutangular triangle; compare त्र्यस्र, जात्य, त्रिभुज and वहिर्लम्ब. E. अन्तर् and लम्ब, ‘lit. where the perpendicular falls within’.
3895: अन्तर्लीन Tatpur. m. f. n. (-नः-ना-नम्) Inherent, innate, e. g. the obvious meaning of a word (प्रत्यक्षवृत्तयः ex-plained by अन्तर्लीनाः) or, brightness as the quality of a pearl (शुक्तिगर्भभासा = तासां (शुक्तीनां) अन्तर्लीनदीप्त्या). E. अन्तर् and लीन.
3896: अन्तर्लोम Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-मः-मा-मम्) Having the hairy side inwards (as a wrapper &c.). E. अन्तर् and लोमन्, samās. aff. अप्.
3897: अन्तर्वंश I. Tatpur. m. (-शः) The same as अन्तःपुर. II. Avyayībh. (-शम्) Amongst the wives of a king, in the gynæceum. E. अन्तर् and वंश.
3898: अन्तर्वंशिक m. (-कः) Superintendent of the women's apart-ments, of a gynæceum. Also आन्तर्वंशिक. E. accord. to some, from अन्तर्वंश I., acc. to others, from अन्तर्वंश II., taddh. aff. ठक्; the absence of Vṛddhi is ascribed to the meaning of the word being conventional (संज्ञा).
3899: अन्तर्वण I. Tatpur. m. f. n. (-णः-णा-णम्) Situated in the middle of, or in, a forest; e. g. व्यवहितमविजानती किला-न्तर्वणभुवि वल्लभमाभिमुख्यभाजम्. II. Avyayībh. (-णम्) Within a forest. E. अन्तर् and वन (for the change of न to ण v. s. v. अन्तर् V. 1.)
3900: अन्तर्वत् 1. m. f. n. (-वान्-वती-वत्) 	1 Occupying the in-terior, e. g. of a hall, a house, घटः ‘a jar in the interior of a hall’; अन्तर्वती शाला ‘a hall in the interior of another hall’. 	2 Probably the same as आत्मवत् (comp. the mean-ing of अन्तर् IV. 2.), selfpossessed, composed, as in the vaidik instance पुमानन्तर्वान्त्स्थविरः पयस्वान्वसोः कबन्धमृ-षभो बिभर्ति; (it has been proposed somewhere to translate अन्तर्वत् in this instance ‘pregnant’). 2. f. (-त्नी; in the Vedas also -वती) A pregnant woman. [As the instance अन्तर्वती शाला has been taken from the Kāśikā on Pāṇ. IV. 1. 32, it is necessary to observe that Bhaṭṭojidīkṣsta in the Prauḍhamanor. rejects this forma-tion together with the counter-instance पतिवती in the same rule: ‘यत्तु प्राचान्तर्वती पतिवतीति प्रत्युदाहृतं तदयुक्तम्’.] E. अन्तर्, taddh. aff. मतुप् and āgama नुक्.
3901: अन्तर्वमि Tatpur. f. (-मिः) Indigestion. E. अन्तर् and वमि.
3902: अन्तर्वर्तिन् Tatpur. m. f. n. (-र्ती-र्तिनी-र्ति) Being within, included by; as the latter part of a compound; e. g. ननु तर्हि प्रबन्धान्तर्वर्तिनां केषामपि नीरसानां पद्यानां काव्यत्वं न स्यात्; or सूर्यान्तर्वर्ती ब्रह्मैव. E. अन्तर् and वर्तिन्.
3903: अन्तर्वसत् Tatpur. m. f. n. (-न्-न्ती-त्) Being within, included in or by; e. g. तेनाम्भसां सारमयः पयोधेर्दध्रे मणिदीधिति-दीपिताशः । अन्तर्वसन्बिम्बगतस्तदङ्गे साक्षादिवालक्ष्यत यत्र लोकः. E. वस् with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. शतृ.
3904: अन्तर्वसुत्रिरात्र Tatpur. m. (-त्रः) One of the sacrifices of three day's duration. See त्रिरात्र. E. अन्तर्वसु and त्रिरात्र.
3905: अन्तर्वस्त्र Tatpur. n. (-स्त्रम्) A lower garment; comp. अन्तर्वा-सस् and अन्तर. E. अन्तर् and वस्त्र.
3906: अन्तर्वा Tatpur. (ved.) See अन्तर्वावत्. E. वा, with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. विच्.
3907: अन्तर्वाणि Bahuvr. m. (-णिः) One conversant with sacred sciences (acc. to a comm.: ‘one who understands but cannot communicate them’ lit. ‘who keeps his wisdom within’). E. अन्तर् and वाणी.
3908: अन्तर्वावत् I. Tatpur. m. f. n. (-वन्-वन्ती-वत्) (ved.) Con-cealed, hidden; अन्तर्वावदकृणोज्ज्योतिषा तमः ‘he has hidden darkness with light’. E. वा, in the intens., with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. शतृ. II. m. f. n. (-वान्-वती-वत्) (ved.) Endowed with trea-sures or with sons, cattle &c. in its interior; अन्तर्वावत्क्षयं दधे ‘he possesses a dwelling abounding internally with treasures or with sons &c.’. E. अन्तर्वा, taddh. aff. मतुप्; Sāyaṇa explains अन्तर्वा as meaning liter. ‘going within, being within, belonging to’ and thus assuming the sense of treasure &c.; he makes it optional, however, to consider in the latter instance अन्तर्वावत् as representing also अन्त-र्वावद्, when the word would come from अन्तर् and वावद् ‘speaking much’ the intens. of वद्, kṛt aff. क्विप्, the sense remaining the same, but the word being then a Tatpurusha.
3909: अन्तर्वावद् Tatpur. See the E. of the preceding.
3910: अन्तर्वाष्प Bahuvr. m. (-ष्पः-ष्पा-ष्पम्) 	1 Containing tears. 	2 With suppressed tears. (In such words or passages as अन्तर्वाष्पभरोपरोधिगदितम् or निगृह्यान्तर्वाष्पम्, the word अन्तर् is not compounded with वाष्प, but in the former instance belongs to उपरोधि preceded by वाष्पभर, in the latter, as a separate word, to निगृह्य.) E. अन्तर् and वाष्प.
3911: अन्तर्वासस् Tatpur. n. (-सः) A lower garment; compare अन्तर्वस्त्र and अन्तर I. 1. 1. E. अन्तर् and वासस्.
3912: अन्तर्विगाहन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) Entering, entrance. E. अन्तर् and विगाहन.
3913: अन्तर्विद्वस् Tatpur. m. f. n. (-द्वान्-दुषी-द्वस्) Knowing what is between (ved.; acc. to Sāyaṇa, scil. heaven and earth); अन्तर्विद्वांँ अध्वनः ‘knowing the paths between (heaven and earth). E. अन्तर् and विद्वस्.
3914: अन्तर्वेग Tatpur. m. (-गः) Inward fever. E. अन्तर् and वेग.
3915: अन्तर्वेदि I. Tatpur. m. (-दिः) 	1 The space within the sacrificial ground; e. g. आ संस्थातोरन्तर्वेद्यां सीदन्ति. 	2 The Duab or the country between the Gaṅgā and Yamunā rivers. Also अन्तर्वेदी. II. Avyayībh. (-दि) Within the sacrificial ground; op-pos. to वहिर्वेदि. E. अन्तर् and वेदि.
3916: अन्तर्वेदी Tatpur. (-दी) The same as अन्तर्वेदि. E. अन्तर् and वेदी.
3917: अन्तर्वेश्म Avyayībh. 	1 Within a house. 	2 In a gynæceum; comp. आन्तर्वेश्मिक. E. अन्तर् and वेश्मन्. Also अन्तर्वेश्मम्.
3918: अन्तर्वेश्मन् Tatpur. n. (-श्म) 	1 The interior of a house; e. g. संध्यां चोपास्य शृणुयादन्तर्वेश्मनि शस्त्रभृत्. 	2 A gynæceum; comp. अन्तःपुर, अन्तर्वंश, अन्तर्गृह.
3919: अन्तर्वेश्मम् Avyayībh. The same as अन्तर्वेश्म. E. अन्तर् and वेश्मन्, samās. aff. टच्.
3920: अन्तर्वेश्मिक. An incorrect word instead of आन्तर्वेश्मिक q. v.
3921: अन्तर्हणन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) Striking in the middle; e. g. वेश्मान्तर्हणनं कोपान्मम शत्रोः करिष्यतः &c. E. अन्तर् and हनन; for the change of न् to ण् see s. v. अन्तर् III.
3922: अन्तर्हनन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) The name of a village in the country of the Bāhīkas. Comp. अन्तर्घण and अन्तर्घन.
3923: अन्तर्हस्त Tatpur. m. f. n. (-स्तः-स्ता-स्तम्) In the hand, within reach. E. अन्तर् and हस्त.
3924: अन्तर्हस्तीन m. f. n. (-नः-ना-नम्) Being in the hand, within reach. E. अन्तर्हस्त, taddh. aff. ख.
3925: अन्तर्हास Tatpur. m. (-सः) A sly or suppressed laugh. E. अन्तर् and हास.
3926: अन्तर्हित Tatpur. m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) 	1 Interposed, separated, e. g. यूनि चान्तर्हितेऽप्राप्तिः scil. चतुर्थादिना; or उदात्त-पूर्वं नियतं विवृत्त्या व्यञ्जनेन च स्वर्यतेऽन्तर्हितम्. 	2 Covered, e. g. अयस्तप्तं तु पाणिभ्यामर्कपत्रैस्तु सप्तभिः । अन्तर्हितं हरन्. 	3 Concealed, hidden, e. g. आयातेन दशास्यस्य संस्थितो ऽन्तर्हितश्चिरम्. 	4 Disappeared, vanished away, e. g. व्रज सुखमायाहीनश्रीरित्यन्तर्हितः शमायाहीनः.-- E. धा with अन्तर्, kṛt aff. क्त.
3927: अन्तर्हितात्मन् Bahuvr. m. (-त्मा) A name of epithet of Śiva, lit. ‘of hidden mind’. E. अन्तर्हित and आत्मन्.
3928: अन्तर्हृदय Tatpur. n. (-यम्) The interior of the heart. E. अन्तर् and हृदय.
3929: अन्तलोप Tatpur. m. (-पः) (In Grammar.) The rejection or dropping of the final of a word. E. अन्त and लोप.
3930: अन्तवचन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) The meaning of the word अन्त; e. g. a particle in such a sense. E. अन्त and वचन.
3931: अन्तवत् I. m. f. n. (-वान्-वती-वत्) Finite, having a term or end, perishable. E. अन्त, taddh. aff. मतुप्. II. ind. (In Grammar.) Like the end or final (of a word); e. g. एकः पूर्वपरयोरिति योऽयमेकादेशो विधीयते स पूर्व-स्यान्तवद्भवति. E. अन्त, taddh. aff. वति.
3932: अन्तवत्त्व n. (-त्त्वम्) Finiteness, perishableness; e. g. अन्त-वत्त्वमसर्वज्ञता वा (scil. ईश्वरस्य). E. अन्तवत्, taddh. aff. त्व.
3933: अन्तवद्भाव Tatpur. m. (-वः) (In Grammar.) The being like the end or final (of a word); e. g. खट्वाभिरित्यत्रान्तवद्भावा-भावादतो भिस् ऐसिति न भवति. E. अन्तवत् II. and भाव.
3934: अन्तवह्नि Tatpur. m. (-ह्निः) The fire that is to destroy the world. E. अन्त and वह्नि.
3935: अन्तवासिन् Tatpur. The same as अन्तेवासिन् q. v. and comp. अन्तसद्. E. अन्त and वासिन्.
3936: अन्तवेला Tatpur. f. (-ला) The time of death. E. अन्त and वेला.
3937: अन्तशय्या Tatpur. f. (-य्या) 	1 The place for burial or burning. 	2 A bier. 	3 Death. 	4 A bed or mat on the ground. E. अन्त and शय्या.
3938: अन्तश्चैतन्य Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-न्यः-न्या-न्यम्) The same as अन्तः-सञ्ज्ञ q. v. E. अन्तर् and चैतन्य.
3939: अन्तसत्क्रिया Tatpur. f. (-या) The funeral honours or cere-monies. Comp. अन्त्यकर्मन्. E. अन्त and सत्क्रिया.
3940: अन्तसद् Tatpur. m. (-द्) A pupil (lit. one who lives near sc. the Guru); comp. अन्तेवासिन् and अन्तिषद्; e. g. मृगा-स्तमुपासते गुरुमिवान्तसदः. E. अन्त and सद्.
3941: अन्तस्ताप I. Tatpur. m. (-पः) Inward heat, burning pain. II. Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-पः-पा-पम्) Burnt within, having inward heat or pain. E. अन्तर् and ताप.
3942: अन्तस्तुषार Tatpur. or Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-रः-रा-रम्) Inward cold. E. अन्तर् and तुषार.
3943: अन्तस्तोय Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-यः-या-यम्) Containing water. E. अन्तर् and तोय.
3944: अन्तस्त्य n. (-स्त्यम्) Entrail, bowels (in the Veda also figu-rasively). E. अन्तर्, taddh. aff. त्यप्.
3945: अन्तस्थ Tatpur. I. m. f. n. (-स्थः-स्था-स्थम्) Being, standing in the end. E. अन्त and स्थ. II. 1. m. f. n., 2. m. plur. and 3. f. The same as अन्तःस्थ; the dropping of the Visarga being optional before स् followed by a hard consonant.
3946: अन्तस्थीय m. f. n. (-यः-या-यम्) Referring, belonging to a semivowel &c.; see अन्तःस्था. E. अन्तस्थ II., taddh. aff. छ.
3947: अन्तस्पथ Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-थः-था-थम्) (ved.) Being in hollows (of mountains), in abysses; an epithet of the Winds. E. अन्तर् and पथिन्, samās. aff. अ (the word is noticed by the Prātiśākhyas on account of its change of र् to स् before प).
3948: अन्तस्वरित (In Grammar.) I. Tatpur. m. (-तः) The swarita (q. v.) accent on the last syllable. E. अन्त and स्वरित, scil. स्वर. II. Bahuvr. n. (-तम्) A word which has the swarita accent on the last syllable. E. The same, scil. पद.
3949: अन्तादि Dwandwa du. (-दी) End and beginning; also आ-द्यन्त. E. अन्त and आदि.
3950: अन्तादिवत् ind. Like the end (of a preceding word) and the beginning (of a following one). E. अन्तादि, taddh. aff. वति.
3951: अन्तावसायिन् m. (-यी) 	1 A Chāṇḍāla, a man of a Śūdra father and Brāhmaṇī mother. 	2 A barber. 	3 The name (probably a nickname) of a Muni. Comp. अन्त्यावसायिन्. E. अन्त and अवसायिन् (सो with अव, kṛt aff. णिनि) acc. to the native explanation ‘because he has the business of finishing off the end sc. of the nails i. e. of paring them’; but more probably ‘one who is engaged in the lowest (cf. अन्त IV. I.) occupations’. This word is therefore not con-nected with अन्तेवासिन् q. v. An incorrect reading is अन्ता-वशायिन्.
3952: अन्ति I. ind. Near, in the proximity of, before, in the pre-sence of. E. According to the native etym. an abbreviation of अन्तिक; but more probably arising from a common origin with अन्त; see the Preface. II. denom. parasm. (-न्तयति) To make an end of, to destroy. E. अन्त, denom. aff. णिच्. III. f. (-न्तिः) (In theatrical language.) An elder sister. E. An abbreviation of अन्तिका.
3953: अन्तिक I. 1. m. f. n. (-कः-का-कम्) Near, proximate. Comp. अन्त, अन्तर, अन्तम, अन्ति, अन्तिकतम, अन्तितम, अन्तिय, अन्त्य.--The words नेदीयस् and नेदिष्ठ are considered as the comparative and superl. of अन्तिक.--In the dramas जनान्तिकम् ‘what is spoken apart to a person so that none else may hear’ is opposed to स्वगतम् ‘what is spoken to one's self’. 2. n. (-कम्) Vicinity, neighbourhood. [अन्तिकात् forms Tatpur. compounds with a following kṛt formation in क्त (i. e. with a past participle), e. g. अन्तिकादागत;--such a word being a compound, because it has but one accent--; अन्तिकम्, अन्तिकेन, अन्तिकात् and अन्तिके are, besides in their literal acceptations, used like prepositions with a noun following or preceding in the genit. or ablat.; e. g. अन्तिकं ग्रामस्य or ग्रामात् ‘near a village’. The correctness of the restriction enjoined by some grammarians, not to com-bine the ablat. अन्तिकात् with a noun in the ablat., is de-nied by Patanjali and his comm.; comp. the instance s. v. दूर।--अन्तिकात् (lit. from the vicinity of) occurs also in the sense of ‘from’, much in the same manner as the ablat. सकाशात्; e. g. क्रीणीयाद्यस्त्वपत्यार्थं मातापित्रोर्यम-न्तिकात् । स क्रीतकः &c.; or नापराध्नीदियं किंचिदभ्रश्यत्पत्यु-रन्तिकात्. NB. Words like केशान्तिक, नासान्तिक, ग्रहणा-न्तिक, आमरणान्तिक, प्राणान्तिक are not compounds of केश, नासा &c. and अन्तिक, but deriv. with taddh. aff. ठन् of केशान्त, नासान्त &c.] E. अन्त or अन्ति, taddh. aff. ठन्. II. f. (-का) A fire place, a furnace. Also अन्ती and अन्दिका. E. The native comm. derive it from अन्त्, kṛt aff. ण्वुल् ‘because it connects with itself the cooking uten-sils’; but though a similar ellipsis is implied by its synon. अधिश्रयणी, the same notion might be obtained by con-necting its etym. with that of अन्तिक. III. f. (-का) The name of a plant (Echites scholaris), a decoction of which is used for one of the urinary dis-eases. E. Perhaps from अन्ति II., denom. of अन्त, kṛt aff. ण्वुल्, the fem. of अन्तक; compare its synonyme शातला (probably from the caus. of शद्). IV. f. (-का) (In theatrical language.) An elder sister, the same as अत्तिका of which it seems to be, like अर्तिका, a degenerated form.
3954: अन्तिकगति Tatpur. f. (-तिः) Going near, approaching. E. अन्तिक and गति.
3955: अन्तिकतम m. f. n. (-मः-मा-मम्) Very near, nearest, close by. Comp. अन्तितम and नेदीयस्, नेदिष्ठ. E. अन्तिक, taddh. aff. तमप्.
3956: अन्तिकता f. (-ता) or अन्तिकत्व n. (-त्वम्) Nearness, vicinity, contiguity. E. अन्तिक्त, taddh. aff. तल् or त्व.
3957: अन्तिकात् See अन्तिक. Considered by the native grammarians as an indecl. E. The ablative of अन्तिक.
3958: अन्तिकादागत Tatpur. m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) Come or ar-rived from near, from. E. अन्तिकात् (see s. v. अन्तिक) and आगत.
3959: अन्तिकार्थ Bahuvr. m. (-र्थः) A word in the sense of near, a synonyme of अन्तिक. E. अन्तिक and अर्थ, scil. शब्द.
3960: अन्तिकाश्रय Tatpur. m. (-यः) 	1 A contiguous support, as that given by a tree to a creeper &c. 	2 The house of a neighbour (according to Hemachandra's Abhidh. 4. 67. (= v. 1001), where the two words उपघ्न and अन्तिकाश्रय are explained by Vallabhagaṇi: पाडोसीघरनाम्नी द्वे; but the quotation added by this comm. from Raghuvanśa 14. 1. would rather refer to the first meaning than qualify a house, as seems required by the context in which these words occur in Hemachandra). E. अन्तिक and आश्रय.
3961: अन्तिकेभव Tatpur. m. f. n. (-वः-वा-वम्) Being near. (Perhaps two distinct words instead of a compound.) E. अन्तिके and भव.
3962: अन्तिगृह Tatpur. n. (-हम्) (ved.) A house in the neighbour-hood, a house near one's own abode. E. अन्ति and गृह.
3963: अन्तितम 1. m. f. n. (-मः-मा-मम्) Very near, nearest, close by. Comp. अन्तिकतम, अन्तितम and नेदीयस्, नेदिष्ठ. 2. n. (-मम्) The nearest place, a place close by, e. g. अन्तितमेऽवरोहति. E. अन्ति (acc. to the native gramm. अन्तिक with the loss of क, but see the E. of अन्ति), taddh. aff. तमप्.
3964: अन्तितस् ind. (ved.) From the neighbourhood, from near. E. अन्ति (acc. to the native gramm. अन्तिक with the loss of क, but see the E. of अन्ति), taddh. aff. तसि, and udātta accent on the first syllable.
3965: अन्तिदेव Tatpur. m. f. n. (-वः-वा-वम्) (ved.) Being near the gods, reaching the gods (an epithet of Soma); the accus. also explained in an adv. sense ‘near the gods’. E. अन्ति and देव.
3966: अन्तिनार Tatpur.(?) m. (-रः) A proper name: according to a Purāṇa, the son of Riteyu, a descendant of Puru; others call him अतिभार or अतिमार or रन्तिनार. E. ?
3967: अन्तिम m. f. n. (-मः-मा-मम्) 	1 Final, ultimate, last. 	2 Very near, nearest, close by (comp. दशान्तिम lit. the nearest to ten i. e. the eleventh). Comp. अन्त्य and the words named s. v. अन्तिक. E. अन्त, taddh. aff. डिमच्.
3968: अन्तिमजिन Karmadh. m. (-नः) The last Jina teacher; see महावीर. E. अन्तिम and जिन.
3969: अन्तिमाङ्क Karmadh. m. (-ङ्कः) (In Arithmetic.) The last unit, the number 9. E. अन्तिम and अङ्क.
3970: अन्तिमाङ्गुलि Karmadh. f. (-लिः) The little finger. E. अन्तिम and अङ्गुलि.
3971: अन्तिमित्र Bahuvr. m. (-त्रः) (ved.) One whose friends are near or at hand. E. अन्ति and मित्र.
3972: अन्तिय 1. m. f. n. (-यः-या-यम्) (ved.) Near, proximate. 2. n. (-यम्) A place in the neighbourhood; e. g. अन्तिये च दूरके सूर्या. Comp. the words named s. v. अन्तिक. E. अन्ति, taddh. aff. यत्.
3973: अन्तिवाम Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-मः-मा-मम्) (ved.) Near or at hand with wealth; an epithet of Ushas. E. अन्ति and वाम.
3974: अन्तिषद् Tatpur. m. f. n. (-द्-द्-द्) (ved.) Sitting near, being near. Comp. अन्तसद्. (This word which is noticed in a Kā-rikā of the Mahābhāṣya to Pāṇ. VI. 4. 149, belongs accord. to another authority to the Gaṇa सुषामादि.) E. अन्ति and सद्.
3975: अन्तिसुम्न Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-म्नः-म्ना-म्नम्) (ved.) (Probably.) Whose happiness is near or present, ever bestowing hap-piness; an epithet of द्यावापृथिवी, heaven and earth. E. अन्ति and सुम्न.
3976: अन्ती f. (-न्ती) A fire place, a furnace; the same as अन्ति-का II. E. A shorter form of अन्तिका q. v.
3977: अन्तेगुरु Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-रुः-रुः-रु) Ending in a heavy (see गुरु) syllable. Also गुर्वन्त. (This word belongs to the Gaṇa आहिताग्न्यादि.) E. अन्ते (locat. of अन्त) and गुरु.
3978: अन्तेवास Tatpur. m. (-सः) A neighbour, a pupil; see अन्ते-वासिन्. E. अन्ते (locat. of अन्त) and वास.
3979: अन्तेवासि Bahuvr. and Avyayībh. In the condition of a pupil (lit. in the condition of one whose habitation is near, scil. the Guru). E. अन्ते (locat. of अन्त) and वास, samās. aff. इच्. [This word is thus explained by the Gaṇaratnamaho-dadhi: अन्ते वासोऽस्मिन्निति अन्तेवासि तिष्ठति; with the additional remark concerning the meaning, and to prevent its identification with the neuter of अन्तेवासिन्, viz. अन्ते-वासी गुरोरित्येभ्यश्च । स शब्दोऽन्ते वसति तच्छील इति णि-न्यन्तः (cf. Pāṇini III. 2. 78.) sic.]
3980: अन्तेवासिन् Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. (-सी-सिनी-सि) Living, or being in, or on, the end or confines. 2. m. (-सी) 	1 A pupil in general (the same as शिष्य), e. g. वैशम्पायनान्तेवासिन् [bases in ऋ when compounded with it as former parts of a Tatpur., retain in the com-position the sign of the genitive, e. g. होतुरन्तेवासिन्, पितु-रन्तेवासिन्]. 	2 An apprentice, one who is learning a mechanical art (according to Nārada, distinct from the शिष्य who is to him the theological student, and one of the four categories of the कर्मकर q. v.; compare besides शिष्य, भृतक and अधिकर्मकृत्).--Both 1. and 2 so called from it being their duty to live near i. e. in the house of the Guru: ‘आचार्यस्य वसेदन्ते कृत्वा कालं सुनिश्चितम् । आचार्यः शिक्ष-येदेनं स्वगृहे दत्तभोजनम्’. 	3 A Chāṇḍāla (q. v.), a man of the lowest tribe (so called because he must live outside of a town; comp. अन्तर I. 1). [In a Prākṛt passage of the Mālatīmādhava अन्तेवासिनी occurs in the sense of a female pupil: साहकस्स मुण्डधारिणी अधोरघण्टणामधेअस्स अन्ते-वासिणी महाप्पहावा करालकुण्डला णाम.] E. अन्ते (locat. of अन्त) and वासिन्.
3981: अन्तोदात्त Tatpur. (In Grammar.) 1. m. (-त्तः) The udātta accent on the last syllable. 2. m. f. n. (-त्तः-त्ता-त्तम्) Pronounced with the udātta accent on the last syllable. E. अन्त and उदात्त.
3982: अन्तोदात्तत्व n. (-त्वम्) (In Grammar.) The being pronounced with the udātta accent on the last syllable. E. अन्तोदात्त, taddh. aff. त्व.
3983: अन्त्य 1. m. f. n. (-न्त्यः-न्त्या-न्त्यम्) 	1 Last, ultimate. (In the Vaiśeṣika philos., अन्त्यो विशेषः is called ‘the ultimate degree of particularity or divisibility, which is the condition of eternal substances only’, viz. the condition of simple, non-compound substances, of atoms, since there is an end of discrimination when this last degree of elementary existence has been arrived at; compare also अन्त्यावस्थिति.) 	2 Final (as the letter of a word). 	3 Nearest, e. g. नवान्त्य nearest to nine i. e. ten. Comp. अन्तिम and the words named s. v. अन्तिक. 	4 Inferior, lowest, belonging to the lowest tribe (see the following meanings). [Tatpur. com-pounds--not Karmadh.--the latter part of which is अन्त्य have the udātta accent on the first syllable.] 2. m. (-न्त्यः) 	1 A man of the lowest tribe. See अन्त्यज. 	2 A Mlechchha or foreigner. See अन्त्यज. 	3 (In Astronomy.) The twelfth or last lunar month, called Phālguna. 	4 A fragrant grass (Cyperus rotundus). See मुस्ता. 	5 m. pl. (-न्त्याः) The name of a people or country; read also अन्धाः or अन्ध्राः or अध्याः. 3. f. (-न्त्या) 	1 A woman of the lowest tribe. See अन्त्यज. 	2 (In Astronomy) thus defined: अहोरात्रवृत्तव्यासार्धं त्रिज्या-तुल्यैरङ्कैरङ्क्यते तावत्त्रिज्यातुल्यं भवति तैरङ्कैर्यावत्कुज्या गण्यते तावच्चरज्यातुल्या भवति । अथ चरज्यया त्रिज्या युतोना अन्त्या-संज्ञा भवति (Siddhāntaśir. Gaṇitādhy. ed. Calc. p. 128). 4. n. (-न्त्यम्) 	1 (In Arithm.) A measure of number, a thousand billions (1000,000,000,000,000). 	2 (In Astronomy.) The last or twelfth sign (लग्न) of the Zodiac, the Pisces or मीनराशि. See अन्त्यभ. 	3 (In Astronomy.) The last or twenty seventh mansion in the circumference of the moon's periodical revolution, the Nakshatra Revatī, the Yoga star of which is ζ Piscium. See अन्त्यभ. E. अन्त, taddh. aff. यत्.
3984: अन्त्यक 1. m. f. n. (-कः-का-कम्) The same as अन्त्य q. v., e. g. fem. 3. 2. हृतिस्त्रिमौर्व्या चरजीवया वा हता द्युमौर्व्या क्षितिजीव-या वा । भक्तान्त्यका स्यादथवान्त्यकाया हृतिर्गुणच्छेदविपर्ययेण. 2. m. (-कः) A man of the lowest tribe; see अन्त्यज. E. अन्त्य, taddh. aff. कन्.
3985: अन्त्यकर्मन् Karmadh. n. (-र्म) Funeral rites; comp. the fol-lowing and अन्तसत्क्रिया. E. अन्त्य and कर्मन्.
3986: अन्त्यक्रिया Karmadh. f. (-या) The same as the preceding. E. अन्त्य and क्रिया.
3987: अन्त्यगोदान Tatpur. n. (-नम्) The giving away of a cow immediately after the performance of the main ceremony of an anuṣṭhāna in expiation of crime. E. अन्त्य and गोदान.
3988: अन्त्यज Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. (-जः-जा-जम्) Latest born, youngest (? comp. अन्तज). 2. m. (-जः) A man of the lowest tribe; the same as अन्त्य. 3. f. (-जा) A woman of the lowest tribe; the same as अन्त्या. [This word (2. and 3.) is explained in various ways. Vijnāneśvara identifies it sometimes with चाण्डाल, in other places he and Kullūka explain it चाण्डालादि ‘Chāṇḍāla and so on’. Of more distinct definitions the following may be noticed: that of Yama, who comprises under the term अन्त्यजाः a washerman, a worker in leather, a dancer, a Varuḍa, a fisherman, a Meda or attendant on women, and a Bhilla (रजकश्चर्मकारश्च नटो वरुड एव च । कैवर्तमेद-भिल्लाश्च सप्तैते ह्यन्त्यजाः स्मृताः); of Samvarta, who com-prises under it a washerman, a hunter, an actor, a flute-player and a worker in leather (रजकव्याधशैलूषवेणुचर्मोप-जीविनाम् &c.); of Āpastamba, who enumerates a Chāṇḍāla, a Meda, a Śvapacha or Śvapāka (the son of an Ugrā woman by a Kshattriya male) and a man who belongs to the Kāpā-lika worshippers of Śiva (चाण्डालमेदश्वपचकपालव्रतचारि-णाम् &c.); of another lawbook which names, a Chāṇḍāla, a Pukkaśa, a Mlechchha, a Śvapāka and a man who has be-come an outcast (चाण्डालं पुष्कसं म्लेच्छं श्वपाकं पतितं तथा). In a similar manner Śātātapa speaks of अन्त्यजा women as of कैवर्ती रजकीं चैव वेणुचर्मोपजीविनीम्; Āpastamba as of म्लेच्छी नटी चर्मकारी रजकी वरुडी तथा, and Uśanas', ‘wife of a man who eats the food of a Kāpālika’ (कापालिकान्न-भोक्तॄणां तन्नारी°) refers probably also to the अन्त्यजा.--Halayudha who calls the Śūdra अन्त्यवर्ण, enumerates the following under the head of अन्तजाति (the same as अन्त्यज): ‘अन्तावसायी चण्डालो निषादश्च जलङ्गमः । श्वपचः पुक्कश-श्चैव मातङ्गः प्लवगः स्मृतः ॥ किराताः शबरा निष्ठ्याः पुलिन्दा नाहला भटाः माला म्लेच्छादयो भिल्लाः कथ्यन्ते ह्यन्तजातयः’.] Comp. अन्त्यजन्मन् and अन्त्यजाति. E. अन्त्य and ज.
3989: अन्त्यजगमन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) Sexual intercourse with an अन्त्यज q. v. (scil. on the part of a woman of the higher tribes). E. अन्त्यज and गमन.
3990: अन्त्यजन्मन् Bahuvr. m. f. (-मा-मा) Of the lowest tribe, a Śūdra man or woman. E. अन्त्य and जन्मन्.
3991: अन्त्यजस्त्री Tatpur. f. (-स्त्री) The wife of a man of the lowest tribe; see अन्त्यज. Also अन्त्यस्त्री. E. अन्त्यज and स्त्री.
3992: अन्त्यजागमन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) Sexual intercourse with an अन्त्यजा q. v. (scil. on the part of a man of the higher tribes). Also अन्त्याभिगमन. E. अन्त्यजा and गमन.
3993: अन्त्यजाति Bahuvr. m. f. (-तिः-तिः) The same as अन्त्यज q. v. (but not the same as अन्त्यजन्मन् q. v.). See also अन्तजाति. E. अन्त्य and जाति.
3994: अन्त्यजातिता n. (-त्वम्) The condition of an अन्त्यजाति or अन्त्यज. E. अन्त्यजाति, taddh. aff. तल्.
3995: अन्त्यधन Karmadh. n. (-नम्) (In Arithmetic.) The last term of an arithmetical progression; comp. मध्यधन and सर्वधन; e. g. व्येकपदघ्नचयो मुखयुक्स्यादन्त्यधनं मुखयुग्दलितं तत् । मध्यधनं पदसंगुणितं तत्सर्वधनं गणितं च तदुक्तम् ‘the in-crease multiplied by the period less one and added to the first quantity is the amount of the last; that added to the first and halved, is the amount of the mean: which multi-plied by the period is the amount of the whole, and is de-nominated the computed sum’. E. अन्त्य and धन.
3996: अन्त्यपद Karmadh. n. (-दम्) (In Arithmetic.) The last or greatest root in the affected square; also called अन्त्यमूल, ज्येष्ठपद, ज्येष्ठमूल and opposed to the आद्यपद or आद्यमूल, कनिष्ठपद or कनिष्ठमूल ‘the least or first root’. These terms are thus explained after Brahmagupta by Colebrooke; ‘the least or first root: that quantity of which the square multi-plied by the given multiplicator and having the given ad-dend added, or subtrahend subtracted, is capable of af-fording an exact square root; the greatest or last root: the square root which is extracted from the quantity so operated upon’. E. अन्त्य and पद.
3997: अन्त्यफलज्या Tatpur. f. (-ज्या) (In Astronomy.) The excen-tricity or the sine of the greatest equation of the centre of a planet. E. अन्त्य-फल and ज्या.
3998: अन्त्यभ Karmadh. n. (-भम्) (In Astronomy.) 	1 The last sign of the Zodiac, the sign Pisces. 	2 The last or twenty seventh mansion in the circumference of the moon's periodical re-volution, the Nakshatra Revatī, the Yoga star of which is ζ Piscium. Compare अन्त्य 4. E. अन्त्य and भ.
3999: अन्त्यमूल Karmadh. n. (-लम्) (In Arithmetic.) The same as अन्त्यपद q. v. E. अन्त्य and मूल.
4000: अन्त्ययुग Karmadh. m. (-गः) The last or Kali age. E. अन्त्य and युग.
4001: अन्त्ययोनि I. Karmadh. (-निः) The lowest place of origin, the lowest tribe. See अन्त्यज. II. Bahuvr. m. f. (-निः-निः) Belonging to the lowest tribe. See अन्त्यज. E. अन्त्य and योनि.
4002: अन्त्ययोनिता f. (-ता) The lowest origin, the lowest degree in the social scale. See अन्त्यज. E. अन्त्ययोनि, taddh. aff. तल्.
4003: अन्त्यलोप Tatpur. m. (-पः) (In Grammar.) The rejection or dropping of the final letter (of a base). E. अन्त्य and लोप.
4004: अन्त्यवर्ण Bahuvr. m. f. (-र्णः-र्णा) A man or woman belong-ing to the last or fourth tribe, a Śūdra or Śūdrī. Compare अन्त्यज, अन्त्यजाति and अन्त्यजन्मन्. E. अन्त्य and वर्ण.
4005: अन्त्यविपुला Karmadh. (-ला) The name of a metre regulated by quantity, a species of the Āryā and a variety of the Vipulā; it consists of two lines with 30 mātrās or (71/2) feet in the first and 27 mātrās or (71/2) feet in the second line, the pause in the first being after the 12th mātrā or 3 	d foot, in the second placed otherwise. Compare आदिविपुला and उभयविपुला. E. अन्त्य and विपुला.
4006: अन्त्यस्त्री Tatpur. (-स्त्री) The same as अन्त्यजस्त्री. E. अन्त्य and स्त्री.
4007: अन्त्यानुप्रास Tatpur. m. (-सः) (In Rhetoric.) Alliteration of the final single or combined consonant together with its vowel, or as the case be, with its Anusvāra and Visarga; rhyme; one of the five varieties of अनुप्रास q. v. It may occur either at the end of a Pāda, or at the end of words in the middle of a Pāda. E. अन्त्य and अनुप्रास.
4008: अन्त्याभिगमन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) The same as अन्त्यजागमन. E. अन्त्या and अभिगमन.
4009: अन्त्यायन Karmadh. n. (-नम्) The last resort. Comp. आन्त्या-यन. E. अन्त्य and अयन.
4010: अन्त्यावसायिन् Tatpur. m. (-यी) A man of a degraded tribe, the offspring of a Niṣādī woman by a Chāṇḍāla male. Ac-cording to Angiras this term comprehends seven classes, viz. चाण्डाल, श्वपच, क्षत्तृ, सूत, वैदेहक, मागध and आयोगव qq. vv.; Vijnāneśvara applies it to Chāṇḍālas and men who have become outcastes in general: ‘चाण्डालपतितादीनाम्’. Comp. अन्तावसायिन् and अन्त्यज. E. अन्त्य and अवसायिन् lit. ‘engaged in the lowest occupations’.
4011: अन्त्यावस्थ I. Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-स्थः-स्था-स्थम्) Being in reduced circumstances; e. g. अन्त्यावस्थोऽपि महान्स्वामिगुणान्न जहाति. II. Karmadh. f. (-स्था) Destruction, death; e. g. यत्नाद्र-क्षन्सुस्थितत्वादनाशं निश्चित्यान्यश्चेतसा भावितेन । अन्त्यावस्था-कालयोग्योपयोगं दध्रेऽभीष्टं नागमापद्धनं वा ।. E. अन्त्य and अवस्था.
4012: अन्त्यावस्थिति Tatpur. f. (-तिः) The size of the Soul when, according to the Jaina doctrine, it has become liberated and thus arrived at a final i. e. atomistic state or one of indivisibility and eternity; or the established condition of the atomistic and consequently eternal size of the Soul, when it has attained its final state. (Compare अन्त्य 1. 1.) Śan-kara gives both interpretations of this word in the Vedānta Sūtra which alludes to the Jaina theory of the atomistic nature of the Soul: ‘अन्त्यावस्थितेश्चोभयनित्यत्वादविशेषः’. E. अन्त्य (in the sense of the genitive, scil. जीव) and अव-स्थिति.
4013: अन्त्याहुति Karmadh. f. (-तिः) A funeral sacrifice. Comp. अन्त्येष्टि. E. अन्त्य and आहुति.
4014: अन्त्याहुतिकर्मन् Tatpur. n. (-र्म) Obsequies. Comp. अन्त्ये-ष्टिक्रिया. E. अन्त्याहुति and कर्मन्.
4015: अन्त्यूति Bahuvr. m. (-तिः) (ved.) Whose protection is (ever) nigh; an epithet of Pūṣan, the Sun. E. अन्ति and ऊति.
4016: अन्त्येष्टि Karmadh. f. (-ष्टिः) A funeral sacrifice. Comp. अन्त्या-हुति. E. अन्त्य and इष्टि.
4017: अन्त्येष्टिक्रिया Tatpur. f. (-या) Obsequies. Comp. अन्त्याहुति-कर्मन्. E. अन्त्येष्टि and क्रिया.
4018: अन्त्र 1. n. (-न्त्रम्) and according to one author. also m. (-न्त्रः). An intestine (mostly used in the plur. अन्त्राणि); e. g. अन्त्रैः कल्पितमङ्गलप्रतिसराः…पिशाचाङ्गनाः; or आत्तस्ना-घ्वन्त्रनेत्रः (a. v. l. instead of आर्त्तः पर्यस्तनेत्रः in the Mā-latīm. ed. Calc. p. 78). According to Suśruta ‘the entrails of a male are three fathoms and a half long, those of a female half a fathom less’ (सार्धत्रिव्यामान्यन्त्राणि पुंसां स्त्री-णामर्धव्यामहीनानि). Charaka divides them in स्थूलान्त्र and क्षुद्रान्त्र, ‘the large and small intestines’. [The definition given by Vijnāneśvara (on Yaju. 3. 94.): क्षुद्रान्त्रं हृत्स्थान्त्रम् is probably therefore to be rendered ‘क्षुद्रान्त्र are the entrails which are nearer the heart’, while the स्थूलान्त्र are near the anus; comp. Suśruta: ‘वातवर्चोनिरसनं स्थूलान्त्रप्रतिबद्धं गुदं नाम मर्म’. The स्थूलान्त्र in taken also by Vijnān. (on Yajn. 3. 96.) in the usual sense, since he writes स्थूलान्त्रगु-दोदराणि प्रसिद्धानि ‘the three words of the text स्थूलान्त्र, गुद and उदर require no remark’.] 2. f. (-न्त्री) The name of a potherb (Convolvulus ar-genteus). [In the passage of the Amarak. छागलान्त्र्यावेगी some comm. divide छागल-अन्त्री-आवेगी, others make a compound of the two first; comp. also अजान्त्री.] E. अम्, uṇ. aff. क्त्र; accord. to another author. uṇ. aff. ष्ट्रन्. Pro-bably, however, a contraction of अन्तर, like अवस्र of अवसर.
4019: अन्त्रकूज Tatpur. m. (-जः) (In Medicine.) Grumbling of the bowels, borborygmi. E. अन्त्र and कूज.
4020: अन्त्रकूजन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) (In Medicine.) The same as the preceding. E. अन्त्र and कूजन.
4021: अन्त्रन्धमि Tatpur. f. (-मिः) Indigestion, flatulence. E. अन्त्र in the accus. and धमि (ध्मा, kṛt aff. इक्); the word is formed on the analogy of the खश्--derivations of ध्मा as नासिकन्धम, नाडिन्धम &c.
4022: अन्त्रपाचक Tatpur. m. (-कः) The name of a plant (Æschy-nomene Grandiflora), the bark, pith and gums of which are poisonous and produce a bad smell in the mouth (आस्यदौ-र्गन्ध्य), a roughness of the body (पारुष्य), headache (शिरोरुज्) and a discharge of saliva (कफसंस्रव). E. अन्त्र and पाचक.
4023: अन्त्रमय m. f. n. (-यः-यी-यम्) Made of entrails. Comp. अन्त्र-स्रज्. E. अन्त्र, taddh. aff. मयट्.
4024: अन्त्रविकूजन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) (In Medicine.) The same as अन्त्रकूज. E. अन्त्र and विकूजन.
4025: अन्त्रवृद्धि Tatpur. f. (-द्धिः) (In Medicine.) The swelling of the scrotum by the descent of the intestines (hernia); one of the seven diseases of the scrotum (comp. besides वात-वृद्धि, पित्तवृद्धि, श्लेष्मवृद्धि, शोणितवृद्धि, मेदोवृद्धि and मूत्रवृद्धि) and considered as generally incurable. E. अन्त्र (in the sense of an instrum.) and वृद्धि, scil. मुष्कस्य.
4026: अन्त्रशिला Bahuvr. f. (-ला) The name of a river rising from the Vindhya mountain; also read अन्तःशिला. E. अन्त्र and शिला, lit. ‘having stones or rocks in her bowels’.
4027: अन्त्रस्रज् Tatpur. f. (-क्) A garland made of entrails, as worn by Nṛsinha. E. अन्त्र and स्रज्.
4028: अन्त्राद Tatpur. m. (-दः) (In Medicine.) One of the seven varieties of worms found in the stomach. E. अन्त्र and आद, scil. कृमि, lit. ‘eating the intestines’.
4030: अन्द्(अदि-भ्वादि-उदात्त-उदात्तेत्) r. 1st cl. par. (अन्दति-अनात्-आनन्द; see अन्त्) To bind. (The Draviḍa pro-vincialism of this radical is अन्त् q. v. Comp. also ईन्त्. The real occurence of this radical which is inflected in the Dhātuparāyaṇa of Hemachandra, as far as the forms given are concerned, but not in the Dhātuvṛtti of Mādhava who inflects अन्त् q. v., is very doubtful. See the Preface.)
4031: अन्द 1. m. (-न्दः) Binding. 2. f. (-न्दा) Perhaps the same as अन्दिका. (Both forms given on the authority of Hemachandra's Dhātuparā-yaṇa; their real occurence is doubtful.) E. अन्द्, kṛt aff. अच्. See the Preface.
4032: अन्दिका f. (-का) A fire-place, a furnace. E. See अन्तिका of which it is a weaker form.
4033: अन्दु f. (-न्दुः) 	1 A chain, a fetter. 	2 An iron heel chain for an elephant's foot. 	3 An ornament worn round the ancles. Comp. the following and अन्दू. E. अन्द्, uṇ. aff. कु; but see the Preface.
4034: अन्दुक m. (-कः) The same as अन्दु. Comp. अन्दूक. E. अन्दु, taddh. aff. क, or accord. to another author. कन्.
4035: अन्दू f. (-न्दूः) The same as अन्दु. E. अन्द्, uṇ. aff. कू; but see the Preface.
4036: अन्दूक m. (-कः) The same as अन्दू. Comp. अन्दुक. E. अन्दू, taddh. aff. क or accord. to some कन्.
4037: अन्दोलन n. (-नम्) 	1 Swinging. 	2 A swing. E. अन्दोलि, kṛt aff. ल्युट्.
4038: अन्दोलि denom. par. (-लयति) To swing. Comp. दुल्, हि-न्दोलि and हिल्लोलि. For the E. see the Preface.
4039: अन्दोलित m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) Swung. E. अन्दोलि, kṛt aff. क्त.
4040: अन्द्रक m. (-कः) The name of a king of the Sunga dynasty, a son of Vasumitra; his name is also given अन्तक, आर्द्रक or भद्रक. E. unknown.
4041: अन्ध्(अन्ध-चुरादि-परस्मैपदिन्) r. 10th cl. par. (अन्धयति--Desid. अन्दिधयिषति) 	1 To be blind. 	2 To make blind. (This radical is more likely in these meanings a denomin. of अन्ध, instead of अन्ध ‘blind’ q. v. being a derivative of अन्ध्.)
4042: अन्ध 1. m. f. n. (-न्धः-न्धा-न्धम्) 	1 Blind; lit. and figur. 	2 Mak-ing blind, obstructing the sight (as darkness &c.). 2. n. (-न्धम्) 	1 Darkness. 	2 Water; see also कबन्ध and कमन्ध. 	3 Turbid water, foul water. 	4 (In Astronomy.) The same as अन्त्य(?). 3. m. pl. (-न्धाः) The name of a people or country; also read अन्ध्राः, अन्त्याः or अध्याः. E. The native etym. ‘अन्ध्, kṛt aff. अच्’ might apply to all the meanings but the first; for that of अन्ध ‘blind’ see the Preface.
4043: अन्धक 1. m. f. n. (-न्धकः-न्धिका-न्धकम्) Blind. E. अन्ध, taddh. aff. क. 2. m. (-कः) A proper name of: 	1 a demon, a son of Kaśyapa and Diti ‘with thousand arms and heads, two thousand eyes and feet and called Andhaka because he walked like a blind man although he saw very well’; in his attempt of taking a Pārijāta tree of the Swarga he was slain by Śiva (see अन्धकघातिन्, अन्धकरिपु); 	2 a grandson of Kroṣṭṛ, and son of Yuddhājita, who together with his brother Vṛṣṇi is the ancestor of the celebrated family of the Andhaka-Vṛṣṇis; 	3 a grandson of Vṛṣṇi (the brother of Andhaka) and son of Śvaphalka by Gāṇḍinī; 	4 a son of Sattwat, be-longing to the same family, by Kauśalyā; 	5 a son of Bhīma (of the same family) and father of Revata. [The forgoing lineage, 2--5, is taken from the Harivanśa. In the Linga Purāṇa an Andhaka is a son of Nahusha who, according to other Purāṇas, is the ancestor of Kroṣṭṛ; in the Kūrma Purāṇa an Andhaka is a son of Anśa and father of Sāttvata, while in the Viṣṇu P. a prince of that name is mentioned as the son of Sāttvata who is apparently the same as the Sattwat of the Hariv.] 	6 The name of a Muni (in the Padma-purāṇa). 3. m. plur. (-काः) The descendants of Andhaka (2. 2), (usually mentioned together with the Vṛṣṇis; see अन्धक-वृष्णि), apparently the ancient inhabitants of Berar. 4. f. (-न्धिका) 	1 Night. 	2 A kind of play or gambling. 	3 A disease of the penis (? the same as सर्षपी q. v.). 	4 A diseased eye. 	5 A woman. [The two latter meanings from the Śabdaratnāvalī, where the word is thus explained: अन्धिका रजनी नारी द्यूतभेदेऽक्ष्णि दूषिते.] E. अन्ध, taddh. aff. कन्.
4044: अन्धकघातिन् Tatpur. m. (-ती) The slayer of the demon An-dhaka q. v., an epithet of Śiva. Comp. the following. E. अन्धक and घातिन्.
4045: अन्धकरिपु Tatpur. m. (-पुः) 	1 A name of Śiva (the ennemy of Andhaka q. v.). Comp. the preceding and अन्धकारि, अन्धकासुहृद्. 	2 A name of Sun, Fire and Moon, figur., as destroyers of darkness (according to Rādhākāntadeva). 	3 (In Astronomy.) The same as the Nakshatra आर्द्रा q. v.(?). E. अन्धक and रिपु.
4046: अन्धकवर्त Tatpur.(?) m. (-र्तः) The name of a mountain. See अन्धकवर्तीय. E. अन्धक and वर्त.
4047: अन्धकवर्तक Dwandwa n. (-कम्) The blind man and the quail (the subject of a fable so called); see the following. E. अन्धक and वर्तका.
4048: अन्धकवर्तकीय m. f. n. (-यः-या-यम्) As in the fable of the blind man and the quail; viz. when the blind man put his feet over the quail (‘अन्धकस्य वर्तकाया उपर्यन्तःपादन्यास उच्यते । तत्तुल्यमन्धकवर्तकीयम्’); said, according to another authority, of a strange event which occurs unexpectedly; compare similar expressions as काकतालीय, खल्वाटविल्वीय, अर्धजरतीय, श्येनकपोतीय, घुणाक्षरीय, शरपुरुषीय, शर्क-रोन्मज्जनीय, अजाकृपाणीय, तिन्दुकीज्योतिषिकीय, &c. E. अन्धकवर्तक, taddh. aff. छ.
4049: अन्धकवर्तीय m. pl. (-याः) The name of a warrior tribe in-habiting the mountain Andhakavarta. E. अन्धकवर्त, taddh. aff. छ.
4050: अन्धकवृष्णि Dwandwa n. pl. (-ष्ण्यः) The descendants of An-dhaka and Vṛṣṇi qq. vv., a celebrated tribe in which, amongst others, Vāsudeva was born. Comp. also श्वाफल्कचैत्रक, चैत्रकान्धक, शिनिवासुदेव, द्वैप्यभैमायन or द्वैप्यहैमायन. E. अन्धक and वृष्णि, with लुक् of the gotra aff.
4051: अन्धकार Tatpur. m. n. (-रः-रम्) Darkness; lit. and fig. E. अन्ध and कार (कृ, kṛt aff. अण्).
4052: अन्धकारप्रायश्चित्त Tatpur. n. (-त्तम्) A penance mentioned in the Varāha-Purāṇa, to atone for the offence of approaching, in the dark, the image of Viṣṇu in his incarnation as a boar, without a lamp and without the Śāstra; such an offence degrading the offender and exposing him to becoming blind: the penance consists in veiling the eyes during fifteen days, taking only one meal on the following twentieth day and one meal on each twelfth day of the half of a month, and when the penitent is half dead in consequence of such diet, sitting in the water and ultimately eating a dish of barley and rice cooked in cow's urine. He is promised to be rid then of his crime. Another reading of this word is अन्धका-रस्पृष्टप्रायश्चित्त. E. अन्धकार and प्रायश्चित्त.
4053: अन्धकारमय m. f. n. (-यः-यी-यम्) Quite darkness, perfectly dark. E. अन्धकार, taddh. aff. मयट्.
4054: अन्धकारसञ्चय Tatpur. m. (-यः) Complete darkness (lit. a collection of darkness, the negation, as it were, of ‘a col-lection of sun-rays; e. g. यतो यतो यतो यतो रवेर्मरीचिसं-चयः । महान्धकारसंचयस्ततस्ततस्ततस्ततः). E. अन्धकार and सञ्चय.
4055: अन्धकारस्पृष्टप्रायश्चित्त Tatpur. n. (-त्तम्) The same as अन्ध-कारप्रायश्चित्त. E. अन्धकार-स्पृष्ट and प्रायश्चित्त.
4056: अन्धकारि Tatpur. m. (-रिः) A name of Śiva, the slayer of the demon Andhaka q. v. Comp. अन्धकरिपु and अन्धका-सुहृद्. E. अन्धक and अरि.
4057: अन्धकारित m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) Become dark. E. अन्धकार, taddh. aff. इतच्. (This etym. is probably merely given to in-dicate that the word is udātta on the last syllable; which it would not be if अन्धकारित were analyzed (as it really ought to be) as a past partic. of a denomin. अन्धकारि from अन्धकार.)
4058: अन्धकासुर Karmadh. m. (-रः) The demon Andhaka q. v. E. अन्धक and असुर.
4059: अन्धकासुहृद् Tatpur. m. (-द्) A name of Śiva, the slayer of the demon Andhaka q. v. Comp. अन्धकारि and अन्धकरिपु. E. अन्धक and असुहृद्.
4060: अन्धकूप Karmadh. m. (-पः) 	1 A blind well, a well filled up with rubbish or one the mouth of which is hidden. 	2 The name of a hell(?). E. अन्ध and कूप.
4061: अन्धङ्करण m. f. n. (-णः-णी-णम्) Making blind, obfuscating. E. अन्ध and करण (कृ, kṛt aff. ख्युन् with fem. ङीप्).
4062: अन्धतमस् Karmadh. n. (-मः) Great darkness. [Accord. to Pāṇiṇi this form would not be correct, as he wants the compound to become अन्धतमस; it occurs however in the fol-lowing introductory verse of the comm. on the Kirātārjunīya: तद्दिव्यमव्ययं धाम सारस्वतमुपास्महे । यत्प्रसादात्प्रलीयन्ते मो-हान्धतमसश्छटाः. (Comp. अन्धकारसञ्चय.)] E. अन्ध and तमस्.
4063: अन्धतमस Karmadh. n. (-सम्) Great darkness; lit. and figur.; e. g. प्रविशति च (scil. मनः) मोहान्धतमसम्. See also अन्ध-तामस and अन्धातमस. E. अन्ध and तमस्, samās. aff. अच्.
4064: अन्धता f. (-ता) Blindness. [Mentioned in the Sāṅkhya philos. as one of the twenty eight disabilities (see अशक्ति and प्रत्य-यसर्ग) and comprehended in the eleven defects of the senses or इन्द्रियबध q. v.] E. अन्ध, taddh. aff. तल्.
4065: अन्धतामस Karmadh. n. (-सम्) Great darkness. See अन्ध-तमस. E. अन्ध and तामस.
4066: अन्धतामिस्र Karmadh. n. (-स्रम्) (Literally: great darkness and hence) 	1 A division of Tartarus, accord. to Manu the second, accord. to Yājnav. the eighteenth of the twenty-one hells (see नरक). 	2 (In the Sāṅkhya philosophy.) A technical term denoting one of the five subdivisions of the विपर्यय (q. v.) which is one of the four divisions of the प्रत्ययसर्ग (q. v., the creation of mental conditions or con-ditions leading to an affection of the बुद्धि q. v.), the वि-पर्यय comprising the purely negative conditions or those opposed to the understanding of the true principles of cre-ation; among the latter अन्धतामिस्र is the mental condition of excessive grief, arising when a man who has placed his happiness in the pleasures which may be derived from either of the ten provinces of the ten senses (see इन्द्रिय) or from the possession of either of the eight superhuman faculties (see ऐश्वर्य), looses the exercise of the latter or dies in the midst of the enjoyments of the former. E. अन्ध and तामिस्र.
4067: अन्धत्व n. (-त्वम्) The same as अन्धता. E. अन्ध, taddh. aff. त्व.
4068: अन्धपूतना Karmadh. f. (-ना) A female imp or devil, one of the nine evil spirits which are supposed to possess children and to work in them diseases generally believed to be in-curable (see ग्रह); she is imagined ‘of formidable size, tawny, bald and wearing yellow-red garments’. Compare the fol-lowing. E. अन्ध and पूतना.
4069: अन्धपूतनार्त्त Tatpur. m. (-र्त्तः) A child possessed by the demon Andhapūtanā; ‘it dislikes the breast, is troubled with di-arrhœa, hiccough, vomiting and fever, has a bad colour, sleeps on the ground and smells sour’. E. अन्धपूतना and आर्त्त.
4070: अन्धमूषा Karmadh. f. (-षा) A small covered crucible in the shape of the udder of a cow, deep and with one hole in the middle. E. अन्ध and मूषा.
4071: अन्धमूषिका Karmadh. f. (-का) The name of a grass (An-dropogon serratus). See देवताड. E. अन्ध and मूषिका.
4072: अन्धम्भविष्णु Tatpur. m. f. n. (-ष्णुः-ष्णुः-ष्णु) Becoming blind. E. अन्ध and भविष्णु (भू, kṛt aff. खिष्णुच्).
4073: अन्धम्भावुक Tatpur. m. f. n. (-कः-का-कम्) Becoming blind. E. अन्ध and भावुक (भू, kṛt aff. खुकञ्).
4074: अन्धस् n. (-न्धः) 	1 (ved.) Food in general. 	2 Food as offered in sacrifice, Soma or Ghee. 	3 Boiled rice. Comp. अन्न. [वो अन्धसः in the Ṛg-V. 8. 92. 1. is noticed by the Ṛgv. Prātiśā-khya on account of the preservation of अ after ओ.] E. अद्, uṇ. aff. असुन् with नुम् āgama and ध् instead of द्. For the etym. of this word see the Preface.
4075: अन्धातमस Karmadh. n. (-सम्) Great darkness. Comp. अन्ध-तमस and अन्धतामस. [On this word a comm. observes: अन्येषामपीति दीर्घत्वेऽन्धातमसमपीति शाकटायनीया वृत्ति-रिति नन्दिशबरस्वामिमुकुटादयः.] E. अन्ध and तमस with the lengthening of the middle अ.
4076: अन्धालजी Karmadh. f. (-जी) (In Medicine.) One of the forty-four क्षुद्ररोग q. v., viz. ‘round, elevated, compact pimples without an opening and with a little matter, produced by diseased phlegm and air’. E. अन्ध and अलजी.
4077: अन्धाहि Karmadh. m. f. (-हिः-हिः) 	1 A blind snake, belong-ing to the not poisonous class. 	2 A kind of fish, vulg. Kūñchiyā; a species of eel; see कुचिका. [As both meanings do not occur in the same author, the latter is perhaps only a further explanation of the former.] E. अन्ध and अहि.
4079: अन्धीकृत Tatpur. m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) Made blind, lit. and fig.; e. g. अन्धीकृतात्मा स्वोत्सङ्गान्निरस्यत महीतले. E. अन्ध, with taddh. aff. च्वि, and कृत.
4080: अन्धीगु Bahuvr. m. (-गुः) अन्धीगुः श्यावाश्विः is the name of a Ṛṣi, the author of the verses of the Sāmaveda 1. 545 (= I. 6. 2. 1. 1.) and 2. 47-49 (II. 1. 1. 18). E. अन्धी(?) and गो.
4081: अन्धीभूत Tatpur. m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) Become blind, lit. and fig. E. अन्ध, with taddh. aff. च्वि, and भूत.
4082: अन्धु m. (-न्धुः) A well. Also अन्धू. E. अम्, uṇ. aff. कु and ādesā धुक्, or अन्ध्, uṇ. aff. उ; see the Preface.
4083: अन्धुल m. (-लः) The name of a tree (Acacia śirīṣa); see शिरीष. E. unknown.
4084: अन्धू f. (-न्धूः) I. A kind of a tie. E. अन्द्, uṇ. aff. ऊ. See the Preface. II. A well. E. अन्ध्, uṇ. aff. ऊ.
4085: अन्ध्र 1. m. pl. (-न्ध्राः) 	1 The name of a people or country in the Dekhan, probably the northern part of the modern Te-lingana. Comp. आन्ध्र. 	2 The name of a dynasty; see अन्ध्रभृत्य. 2. m. (-न्ध्रः) A man of low caste: the offspring of a Vaideha father and a Kārāvara mother; he lives by killing game and is not allowed to reside within a village or town, but must live under Chaitya-trees, in cemeteries, on moun-tains or in forests; (according to Manu, who embodies in this manner the Andhra-aborigines into the Brahmanical system). Compare also आन्ध्र. E. unknown.
4086: अन्ध्रजाति Tatpur. f. (-तिः) The Andhra caste. E. अन्ध्र and जाति.
4087: अन्ध्रजातीय m. f. n. (-यः-या-यम्) Belonging to the Andhra caste. E. अन्ध्रजाति, taddh. aff. छ.
4088: अन्ध्रभृत्य Karmadh. m. pl. (-त्याः) The name of a dynasty of Andhra kings, apparently of low origin, thirty kings of which are said to have reigned four hundred and sixty-six years, the last in the year 431 or 435 after Chr. E. अन्ध्र and भृत्य (an Andhra by caste and a servant by occupation).
4089: अन्न I. 1. m. f. n. (-न्नः-न्ना-न्नम्) Eaten. [The use of this word, as a past participle of अद्, is restricted, according to He-machandra's Dhātupārāyaṇa, to such passive constructions as correspond with our use of a past partic.; but while जग्ध may be substituted for अन्न also in these cases, जग्ध alone is admissible when ‘eaten’ is used either sub-stantively with a genitive depending on it or impersonally; ‘अद्यर्थाच्चेति वाधारे (आधार is here equivalent to अधि-करण of Pāṇ. III. 4. 76.) क्ते । इदमेषां जग्धम् ॥ पक्षे कर्मणि क्ते । जग्धमन्नम् ॥ भावे । जग्धमनेन ॥’.] 2. n. (-न्नम्) 	1 Food in general, eatable or drinkable; e. g. अन्नं पितृमनुष्येभ्यो देयमप्यन्वहं जलम् (comm.: अन्नग्रहणं सकलादनीयप्रदर्शनार्थम्); or अन्नमिष्टं हविष्यं च दद्यादक्रो-धनोऽत्वरः (comm.: अन्नं भक्ष्यभोज्यलेह्यचोष्यपेयात्मकं पञ्च-विधं दृष्टम्); also elliptically, the eating of food, e. g. सर्वा-न्नानुमतिश्च प्राणात्यये तद्दर्शनात्; comp. also अन्नकाल, अन्न-पानरक्षा &c. In the post-vaidik literature, an exalted eulo-gium of food as the supporter of creation is given e. g. in the Anuśāsanaparvan of the Mahābhārata v. 3204--3251 and 5541 --5562; comp. also अन्नद. 	2 (In the Upanishads and the Vedānta philos.) Food in a metaphysical or mystical sense, the essence of the elementary creation, that of which the coarsest sheath or the coarse body of the Supreme Soul (see अन्नमयकोश and स्थूलशरीर) is framed: the lowest and therefore not truest form in which Brahman (n.) or the Supreme Soul (comp. अन्नब्रह्मन्) manifests itself in its worldly and con-scious existence (‘येऽन्नं ब्रह्मोपासते’; ‘अन्नं ब्रह्मेत्येक आहु-स्तन्न’; see also अन्नज). Compare besides प्राण, मनस्, वि-ज्ञान, आनन्द. In this form the Supreme Soul is also called वैश्वानर, विराज्, विश्व and जाग्रत् qq. vv., e. g. अन्नं वै विराट्; or सैषा विराड्दशसंख्या सत्यन्नं चान्नादिनी च. The process of this manifestation is thus imagined in the Taittirīya Upanishad: in the Supreme Soul originates æther, in æther air and so on in each preceding element successively fire, water, earth, herbs, food, from which comes semen and man; in food originate, too, all other creatures living on this earth (‘अ-न्नाद्वै प्रजाः प्रजायन्ते याः काश्च पृथिवीं श्रिताः । अथोऽन्नेनैव जीवन्ति । अथैनदपि यन्त्यन्ततः । अन्नं हि भूतानां ज्येष्ठं तस्मा-त्सर्वौषधमुच्यते’). In the Vedānta the theory of this primi-tive developement is more intricate; comp. s. v. अन्नमयकोश. (In the Aitareya Upan. food is represented as a being of organised form sprung forth from the heated waters, the process of creation differing materially from that imagined by the Taittirīya and the Vedānta.) 	3 (The latter meaning applied in the doctrine of the Viṣṇuites to) Viṣṇu. 	4 (ved.) Water. 	5 Corn in general (comp. सर्वौषध under meaning 2.). 	6 Boiled rice. [In the two last meanings अन्न is used also as a term of contempt; when combined with मन् cl. 4. in this sense, it depends on the latter in the accusative (not in the dative as similar terms, e. g. तृण, बुस, श्वन् &c. also may); e. g. न त्वान्नं मन्ये यावद्भुक्तं न श्राद्धम् ‘not so much as a grain or a grain of boiled rice &c.’ (but न त्वा तृणं, बुसं, श्वानं or तृणाय, बुसाय, शुने मन्ये); for similar terms comp. also नौ, काक, शुक, शृगाल.] 	7 A soup or sauce made of flesh; see अन्नप्राशन. 	8 A soup or sauce made of rice; see s. v. अन्नमल. 	9 Spirituous liquor made of rice; see s. v. अन्नपेय and अन्नमल. E. अद्, uṇ. aff. क्त; the native gramm. assign to अन्न in the meaning ‘boiled rice’, and probably also in the other meanings, the uṇ. aff. न which is नित्. The Tait-tirīya-Upan. explains अन्न 2. 2. thus: अद्यतेऽत्ति च भूतानि तस्मादन्नं तदुच्यत इति । ‘because it is eaten and because it eats what exists i. e. because what exists becomes again अन्न’. II. m. (-न्नः) The sun. E. According to an Uṇṇādisūtra as quoted in the Siddh. Kaum. and in Nṛsinha's Swara-mañjarī अत्, uṇ. aff. न; acc. to Hemach.'s Dhātupārāyaṇa, अम् (उण्णादौ दम्यमीति ने । अन्नः), uṇ. aff. न.
4090: अन्नकाम Bahuvr. m. (-मः) One desirous of food or plenty; (this word occurs esp. in vaidik passages which speak of sacrifices the performance of which insures the attainment of food or plenty; e. g. पौष्णं श्याममालभेतान्नकामः; or मैत्रं श्वेतमालभेत वारुणं कृष्णमपां चौषधीनां च संधावन्नकामः). Comp. also अन्नाद्यकाम. E. अन्न and काम.
4091: अन्नकाल Tatpur. m. (-लः) Meal time, proper hour for eating. E. अन्न and काल.
4092: अन्नकूट Tatpur. m. n. (-टः-टम्) A large heap of boiled rice; see the following. E. अन्न and कूट.
4093: अन्नकूटयात्रा Tatpur. f. (-त्रा) The festival of the mountain of boiled rice; a festival of the Hindus in the month of November when they make a pile of boiled rice as a type of the hill Govardhana in Vraja, near Mathurā, upheld by Kṛṣṇa for the shelter of the milkmaids. It is called also Govardhanapūjā and observed especially by cowherds. E. अन्नकूट and यात्रा.
4094: अन्नकोष्ठक Tatpur. m. (-कः) 	1 A granary. 	2 Viṣṇu. 	3 The sun. E. अन्न and कोष्ठक.
4095: अन्नगति Tatpur. f. (-तिः) (In Medicine.) The œsophagus, the gullet. E. अन्न and गति.
4096: अन्नगन्धि Bahnvr. m. (-न्धिः) Diarrhœa, dysentery. E. अन्न and गन्ध, samās. ādeśa इ; the compound implying compari-son ‘smelling like boiled rice’; comp. similar formations as पद्मगन्धि, करीषगन्धि, उत्पलगन्धि.
4097: अन्नग्राहक Tatpur. m. (-कः) The seizer of food; an epithet of the vital air अपान q. v.; comp. अन्नायु. E. अन्न and ग्राहक.
4098: अन्नज Tatpur. 1. m. f. n. (-जः-जा-जम्) Produced by food or by the essence of the elementary creation; e. g. कथमन्नजो ऽन्नात्माऽन्नप्रलयोऽहं तस्मादन्नं ब्रह्मेति ‘how (is it that men adore Brahman under the form of अन्न? it is when they think:) I am the product of अन्न, I have the nature of अन्न, I shall be merged again into अन्न, therefore अन्न is Brahman’. 2. n. (-जम्) (In Medicine.) Water in which rice has been boiled, rice gruel. E. अन्न and ज.
4099: अन्नजल Dwandwa n. (-लम्) Support, maintenance. E. अन्न and जल; ‘rice and water’.
4100: अन्नजात Tatpur. m. f. n. (-तः-ता-तम्) The same as अन्नज q. v. E. अन्न and जात.
4101: अन्नजित् Tatpur. m. f. n. (-त्-त्-त्) Conquering food; a vai-dik epithet of sacrificial horses. E. अन्न and जित्.
4102: अन्नजीवन Tatpur.(?) m. f. n. (-नः-नी(?)-नम्) Living through or by अन्न q. v. 2. 2. E. अन्न and जीवन.
4103: अन्नतेजस् Bahuvr. m. f. n. (-जाः-जाः-जः) (ved.) Having the strength or power of अन्न q. v. 2. 2. E. अन्न and तेजस्.
4104: अन्नद Tatpur. m. f. n. (-दः-दा-दम्) Giving food &c., see अन्न; also m. as an epithet of Śiva and f. of Durgā. [Manu promises to a man who gives food, eternal happiness; Yā-jnavalkya, that he will be honoured in the Swarga; the Anu-śāsanaparvan of the Mahābh. however (see the passages quoted s. v. अन्न), gives a detailed account of the various benefits which accrue to the giver of food, and which comprise nearly all conceivable happiness in this and the future world.] E. अन्न and द.
4105: अन्नदातृ Tatpur. m. f. n. (-ता-त्री-तृ) The same as अन्नद. E. अन्न and दातृ.
4106: अन्नदान Tatpur. n. (-नम्) The giving of food (enjoined as a meritorious act; compare अन्नद). E. अन्न and दान.
4107: अन्नदायिन् Tatpur. m. f. n. (-यी-यिनी-यि) The same as अन्नद q. v. E. अन्न and दायिन्.
4108: अन्नदोष Tatpur. m. (-षः) A sin committed with reference to the laws of diet, e. g. by eating garlick, onions, mush-rooms or other prohibited articles of food. E. अन्न and दोष.
4109: अन्नद्वेष Tatpur. m. (-षः) Dislike of food, want of appetite. E. अन्न and द्वेष.
4110: अन्नपति Tatpur. m. (-तिः) The protector of food (a vaidik epithet of Agni, and an epithet of Śiva in the Mahābh.); the Lord of food (an epithet of Savitṛ or the sun). Comp. अन्नपू. E. अन्न and पति.
4111: अन्नपरिवर्त Tatpur. m. (-र्तः) Change of diet (= आहारद्रव्य-विपर्ययः). E. अन्न and परिवर्त.
4112: अन्नपानरक्षा Tatpur. f. (-क्षा) Precaution in eating and drink-ing. (The अन्नपानरक्षाकल्प is the introductory chapter of Suśruta to his toxicology; the bearing of the word is con-veyed by the verse: तस्मात्परीक्षणं कार्यं भृत्यानामादितो नृपैः । अन्ने पाने &c.) Comp. अन्नरक्षा. E. अन्न-पान, Dwandwa, and रक्षा.
4113: अन्नपानविधि Tatpur. m. (-धिः) The properties of eatable and drinkable substances (they are the subject of a chapter in Suśruta's Sūtrasthāna). E. अन्न-पान, Dwandwa, and विधि.
4114: अन्नपू Tatpur. m. (-पूः) Purifier of food, a vaidik epithet of the Sun; comp. अन्नपति. E. अन्न and पू.
4115: अन्नपूर्णा Tatpur. f. (-णा) 	1 A name of Durgā or Pārvatī (lit. ‘full with food’). [“ 	2 Hence applied to a female cook under whose management the daily provision seems blessed and increased. 	3 A term for an alm's bag. 	4 A particular drink-ing vessel used at Benares; so named after the goddess.”] E. अन्न and पूर्ण.
4116: अन्नपूर्वा(?) Bahuvr. f. (-र्वा) A name of Durgā. Comp. the preceding. E. अन्न and पूर्व.
4117: अन्नपेय Bahuvr. n. (-यम्) (ved.) A synonyme of the sacrifice वाजपेय q. v.; वाज in the latter word being a synonyme of अन्न; according to Sāyana: ‘because a spirituous liquor prepared from rice is drunk at that sacrifice’ (वाजशब्दो ऽन्नवाची । अन्नमन्नविकारभूतं सुराद्रव्यं पीयतेऽत्रेति हि व्यु-त्पत्तिः). See अन्न 2. 9. and compare अन्नमल. E. अन्न and पेय.
4118: अन्नप्रद Tatpur. m. f. n. (-दः-दा-दम्) The same as अन्नद q. v. E. अन्न and प्रद.
4119: अन्नप्रलय Tatpur. m. f. n. (-यः-या-यम्) Becoming merged into अन्न (2. 2) q. v., returning to it after death, the reverse of अन्नज q. v. (comp. the passage mentioned under the latter word). E. अन्न and प्रलय.
4120: अन्नप्राश Tatpur. m. (-शः) The same as the following. E. अन्न and प्राश.
4121: अन्नप्राशन Tatpur. n. (-नम्) Giving food to eat, scil. to a child: the seventh of the ten essential rites enjoined to the the three first castes (see संस्कार); it ought to take place according to Āsvālāyana, Manu, Yājnavalkya &c. in the sixth month after a child's birth; according to Kātyāyana and his school in the sixth (or, according to some, in the eighth month) if the child is a boy, in the fifth or seventh, if it is a girl. According to Āsvālāyana a father, if he desire plenty (for his child?) ought to give it a soup or sauce made of goat's flesh (‘आजमन्नाद्यकामः’); if he de-sire holiness, a soup or sauce made of the flesh of a fran-coline patridge, called tittiri (‘तैत्तिरं ब्रह्मवर्चसकामः’); if he desire strength, boiled rice sprinkled over with very little clarified butter, but not fried in butter, as it would then not be moist (‘घृतौदनं तेजस्कामः’) [The restriction made by the comm. in his explanation of the word घृतौदन is not justified by himself, but countenanced by the gloss of Patanjali on a Vārttika (‘संप्रत्ययाच्च तदर्थाध्यवसानम्’) to Pāṇini II. 1. 34]; or if he have no particular desire, boiled rice mixed with curdled milk, honey and clarified butter (‘दधिमधुघृतमिश्रमन्नं प्राशयेत्’). [The word अन्न supplied at आज and तैत्तिर is, as the comm. observes, not to be taken there in its usual sense ‘boiled rice’ but in that of soup or sauce, व्यञ्जन.] When giving the food, whatever be its substance, the father speaks the verse: अन्नपतेऽन्नस्य नो देह्यनमीवस्य शुष्मिणः &c. (Vājas. Sanh. 11. 83.), if the child is a boy; if it is a girl, the ceremony is performed without the recital of the mantra (‘आवृतैव कुमार्यै’).--According to the school of Kātyāyana the food varies still more according to the nature of the desires: that cor-responding with the desire of eloquence is the flesh (pro-bably the sauce made of the flesh of) a skylark (भरद्वाजी); with the desire of plenty, that of a partridge, called क-पिञ्जल; with the desire of quickness that of a fish; with the desire of long life that of the partridge called कृकणा; with the desire of holiness that of the Śaralī bird (आटी); with the desire of all the advantages mentioned before that of all these animals together; the dish must moreover in general contain honey, clarified butter and bits of gold (Reṇuka in his Gṛhyakārikā: ‘मध्वाज्यकनकोपेतं सर्वं तद्युग-पत्प्रभुः । मांसं तच्च भरद्वाज्या यदीच्छेद्वाक्प्रसारिताम् । का-पिञ्जलं चेदन्नाद्यं मात्स्यं च जवनं यदि । आयुश्चेत्कृकणायाश्च तदाट्याश्चेद्ब्रह्मवर्चसम् । सर्वं चेत्सर्वमांसानि सहान्नं प्राशयेच्छु-भम्’); the ceremony is performed while a mantra is in-audibly muttered and the child is sitting on the lap of its mother before the divinity of the family; preparatory pro-cedings are, according to Reṇuka, those connected with the fixing of an auspicious day, the Ābhyudayika-śrāddha (the same as the Vṛddhi-Śr.), austerities, as suspending the breath, meditation on the divinity and oblations (āhutis) with clarified butter while remembering the divine powers of speech (वाच्), the vital airs प्राण and अपान, eye (चक्षुस्) and ear (श्रोत्र), lastly an oblation of चरु (q. v.) to Agni (अग्निः स्विष्टकृत्).--According to Bhavadeva, as quoted by Rādhākānta, the order of the procedings is: fixing of an auspicious day, ablutions, performance of the Vṛddhi-Śrāddha, collecting of the sacrificial fire, making a heap of Kuśagrass(?) (acc. to Reṇuka: of fifty leaves of this grass), then silently throwing into the fire a piece of fuel smeared with clarified butter, of a span's length, then the oblation (homa) which is accompanied with the three sacred words bhūr, bhuvar and svar, then five oblations (āhutis) with clarified butter, then the homa of the five vital airs (प्राण), or instead of the two latter(?) the ceremony practised in the north which begins with the Śāṭyāyana-homa and ends with the hymn called Vāmadevya; these procedings are followed by the essential rite of giving the food and by, what is essential too, the presents to the of-ficiating priest. (Comp. also अन्नभुक्ति.) E. अन्न and प्राशन.
4122: अन्नबुभुक्षु Tatpur. m. f. n. (-क्षुः-क्षुः-क्षु) Desirous of eating food &c., see the meanings of अन्न; (the same notion may also be expressed by अन्नं बुभुक्षुः). E. अन्न and बुभुक्षु.
4123: अन्नब्रह्मन् Karmadh. n. (-ह्म) Brahman (n.) or the Supreme Soul in its lowest form or अन्न (2. 2.) q. v. E. अन्न and ब्रह्मन्.
4124: अन्नब्रह्मविद् Tatpur. m. (-त्) One who considers Brahman (n.) or the Supreme Soul to be the same as अन्न (q. v. 2. 2.). E. अन्नब्रह्मन् and विद्.
4125: अन्नभक्ष Tatpur. m. (-क्षः) The eating of food; e. g. अध-उच्छिष्टोऽन्नभक्षोदकपानेषु गायत्रीजपः. E. अन्न and भक्ष.
4126: अन्नभक्षण Tatpur. n. (-णम्) The same as अन्नभुक्ति q. v. and used also in the same manner. E. अन्न and भक्षण.
4127: अन्नभाग Tatpur. m. (-गः) 	1 A portion of food &c. 	2 Sharing in food, a share in food &c. See अन्न. E. अन्न and भाग.
4128: अन्नभुक्ति Tatpur. f. (-क्तिः) The eating of food; the word oc-curs also as a synonyme of the ceremony अन्नप्राशन, the latter being the action of the father, and अन्नभुक्ति that of the child. E. अन्न and भुक्ति.
4129: अन्नभुज् Tatpur. m. f. n. (-क्-क्-क्) Eating food; also as an epithet of Śiva. E. अन्न and भुज्.
4130: अन्नमय 1. m. f. n. (-यः-यी-यम्) 	1 Made of, consisting of, the metaphysical or mystical अन्न (2. 2.) q. v.; e. g. अन्नमयं हि सोम्यं मनः; the quality of the Supreme Soul in its lowest form of manifestation; see अन्न 2. 2, प्राणमय, मनोमय, विज्ञानमय and आनन्दमय; comp. also अन्नरसमय; अन्नमयो रसः, the same as अन्नरस (2. b.) q. v. 	2 Chiefly (but not entirely) consisting of boiled rice &c. (see the meanings of अन्न); e. g. अन्नमयो यज्ञः. 2. n. (-यम्) Plenty of boiled rice, food &c. [The two latter meanings of this word result from the different inter-pretation of the commentators on Pāṇ. V. 4. 21; as regards the first, it may be observed that अन्नमय is not allowed to mean ‘made of, or consisting of, food, boiled rice &c.’ in the usual, non-mystical sense of this word; the word expressing this notion is आन्न.] E. अन्न, taddh. aff. मयट्.
4131: अन्नमयकोश Karmadh. m. (-शः) The sheath made of अन्न 2. 2., of the essence of the elementary creation, i. e. the material creation: the lowest form in which Brahman (n.) or the Supreme Soul is considered as manifesting itself in its world-ly and conscious existence.--In the Taittirīya-Upan. अन्न of which the material creation is made, is the product of herbs, these of earth and so on in retrogression, of the elements water, fire and æther, the latter being the first product of the Supreme Soul; it would appear therefore that Brahman (n.) as अन्नमयकोश, in this Upanishad, is the totality of the animal kingdom only, since the vegetable kingdom precedes the creation of अन्न which is called also सर्वौषध (see अन्न 2. 2.) and the beings (प्रजाः or भूतानि) originating in अन्न, are represented as living through it (‘अथोऽनेनैव जीवन्ति’); but as अन्न on the other hand, is the essence of the elements preceding it, this form of Brahman would become in the Upanishad, constructively, the same that it is in the Vedānta explicitly, viz. the to-tality of the whole material creation. Yet while the Upa-nishad uses the terms æther, air, fire, water and earth to denote the elements in a general sense, the Vedānta dis-tinguishes between ideal (सूक्ष्म) and real (स्थूल) elements and makes the अन्नमयकोश proceed from the latter which are an artificial mutual combination of portions of the former (see भूत, सूक्ष्मभूत and स्थूलभूत); and while the Upanishad contents itself with the general idea of totality, as expressed above, the Vedānta distinguishes between the conception that may be formed of the Supreme Soul as unity in this totality of the material creation (comp. समष्टि) and the con-ception that may be formed of it as multiplicity in it (comp. व्यष्टि); as unity it is called वैश्वानर or विराज्, as multi-plicity विश्व, in either case it is जाग्रत्.--The forms superior to the अन्नमयकोश are in successive gradation प्राणमयकोश, मनोमयकोश, विज्ञानमयकोश and आनन्दमयकोश qq. vv. (the word कोश being supplied, in the Upanishad, by the comm. to अन्नमय &c.). Compare also सूक्ष्मशरीर and स्थू-लशरीर. E. अन्नमय and कोश. Also written अन्नमयकोष.
4132: अन्नमयकोष Karmadh. m. (-षः) The same as अन्नमयकोश q. v.
4133: अन्नमल Tatpur. n. (-लम्) 	1 Offal, sweepings. 	2 The worst kind of spirituous liquor, viz. सुरा. [The latter meaning requires an explanation: Manu 11. 93 says: सुरा वै मल-मन्नानां &c. and forbids the drinking of the spirituous liquor सुरा to a man of the three first castes; Kullūka in his com-ment seems to take मलमन्नानां or अन्नमल in the general sense of ‘extract of rice’, because सुरा is made from the flower of rice (तण्डुलपिष्टसाध्यत्वात्सुरा अन्नमलम्); but Pulastya, as quoted by Vijnāneśvara in the Mitākṣara names twelve sorts of intoxicating drinks, stating that सुरा is the very worst description amongst them: पानसं द्राक्षं माधूकं खार्जूरं तालमैक्षवम् । मधूत्थं सैरमारिष्टमैरेयं नारिकेलजम् । समा-नानि विजानीयान्मद्यान्येकादशैव तु । द्वादशं तु सुरामद्यं सर्वे-षामधमं स्मृतम्; and Vijnāneśvara in commenting upon the quoted passage of Manu and adducing Pāṇ. II. 1. 34. where the word अन्न means a preparation of rice &c. observes that it is intended to convey in this passage the sense of spirituous liquor, the latter being also an अन्नविकार or preparation of rice, and सुरा being used also in the Sautrā-maṇī libations in the sense of spirituous liquor made of rice: ‘सुरा वै मलमन्नानां पाप्मा च मलमुच्यत इति । अन्नविकार-स्यैव सुरात्वनिर्देशादन्नशब्दस्य चान्नेन व्यञ्जनमित्यादिषु व्रीह्या-दिविकार एव प्रयोगदर्शनाद्गुडमधुनोश्च रसरूपत्वात्तथा सौ-त्रामणीग्रहेषु चान्नविकार एव सुराशब्दस्य श्रुतत्वात् । ’. For this meaning of अन्न compare also अन्नपेय.] E. अन्न and मल.
4134: अन्नरक्षा Tatpur. f. (-क्षा) Precaution in eating; compare अन्नपानरक्षा. E. अन्न and रक्षा.
4135: अन्नरस Tatpur. m. (-सः) 	1 The essential properties of food, esp. the good or salutary properties; e. g. अपथ्यैः सह संभुक्ते व्याधिरन्नरसे यथा ‘just as disease may lurk in the good essence of food when it is eaten with unwholesome sub-stances’; or यमस्त्वन्नरसं प्रादात् ‘Yama gave (Nala) the distinguished properties of food’ (comm. ‘अन्नरसं यादृशे तादृशेऽप्यन्ने विशिष्टरसवत्ताम्’). 	2 (In the Taittirīya Upan.) 	a. Semen virile, as the essence of अन्न 2. 2.; 	b. the same as अन्न 2. 2. q. v. See the following. E. अन्न and रस.
4136: अन्नरसमय m. (-यः) (In the Taittirīya Upanishad.) 	1 Made of the essence of अन्न 2. 2., being the very essence of अन्न 2. 2. q. v., viz. man, ‘अन्नाद्रेतः । रेतसः पुरुषः । स वा एष पुरुषोऽन्नरसमयः ।’. 	2 The same as अन्नमयकोश q. v. ‘तस्माद्वा एतस्मादन्नरसमयादन्योऽन्तरात्मा प्राणमयः’. E. अन्नरस, taddh. aff. मयट्.
4137: अन्नलिप्सा Tatpur. f. (-प्सा) Craving, appetite. E. अन्न and लिप्सा.
4138: अन्नवत् m. f. n. (-वान्-वती-वत्) Rich in food. E. अन्न, taddh. aff. मतुप्.
4139: अन्नवस्त्र Dwandwa n. (-स्त्रम्) Food and clothing, the ne-cessaries of life. Comp. अन्नाच्छादन. E. अन्न and वस्त्र.
4140: अन्नवाहिस्रोतस् Tatpur. n. (-तः) (In Medicine.) The œso-phagus, the gullet. E. अन्न-वाहिन् and स्रोतस्.
4141: अन्नविकार Tatpur. m. (-रः) 	1 Transformation of food; used in general of any preparation of an article of food, e. g. of सक्तु, पुरोडाश, सुरा, यवसुरा, पिष्टसुरा (comp. s. v. अन्न-मल); according to an observation of Vardhamāna, however, only of an artificial preparation, of made dishes, e. g. of sweetmeats, शष्कुलीमोदक &c.
